member.name: T:Leadtools.Codecs.CodecsXpsLoadOptions
member.summary: Provides the options for loading Open XML Paper Specification (XPS) documents as a raster image.

remarks.para: Open XML Paper Specification (XPS) files have no physical width or height in pixels. You can use the to control how the final document is rendered as a raster image. For more information, refer to .
For more information, refer to File Formats - XPS Format.

member.name: T:Leadtools.Codecs.CodecsXpsSaveOptions
member.summary: Provides the options for saving a raster image as an Open XML Paper Specification (XPS) document.

remarks.para: The Open XML Paper Specification Format supports saving images with either PNG or JPEG Compression.
The following table shows the quality factor used when an image is saved with a particular format:

member.name: P:Leadtools.Codecs.CodecsXpsSaveOptions.PngQualityFactor
member.summary: Gets or sets the PNG quality factor used saving a raster image as an Open XML Paper Specification (XPS) document.
member.value: Any value between 0 and 9. 0 = (default compression), 1 (fastest compression) ... 9 (highest compression ratio). Default value is 3.
member.remarks: The object will use the value when images are saved with the RasterImageFormat.Xps format.

member.name: P:Leadtools.Codecs.CodecsXpsSaveOptions.JpegQualityFactor
member.summary: Gets or sets the JPEG quality factor used saving a raster image as an Open XML Paper Specification (XPS) document.
member.value: A value from 2 to 255, where 2 is the highest quality and 255 is the most compression. You can also use a factor of 0 to produce lossless JPEG compressed images. Default value is 2 (Highest quality).

remarks.para: The object will use the value when images are saved with the following formats:

For more information, refer to File Formats - XPS Format.

member.name: M:Leadtools.Codecs.CodecsExtensionList.GetAudioData(System.Int32)
member.summary: Gets the embedded audio data from the specified extension list.
member.param: Index of the audio stream to retrieve. The extensions may have more than one audio stream. This index is 0-based. Therefore, the first stream is stream 0, the second stream is stream 1, etc. To retrieve all the audio streams, retrieve the streams one by one until an empty is returned (empty will have a RasterNativeBuffer.Data set to IntPtr.Zero and RasterNativeBuffer.Length set to 0.
member.returns: A object containing the audio data.

remarks.para: The audio data is stored inside extensions in the WAVE format.
The audio data can be played directly from memory, or the data can be written to a disk file and played from the disk. When writing the audio data to a disk file, give the file a .WAV extension.
The audio data pointer returned is freed automatically when this object is disposed. so do not try to free this memory.

member.example: For an example, refer to RasterCodecs.ReadExtensions.

java.pre: public RasterNativeBuffer getAudioData(int stream)

member.name: T:Leadtools.Codecs.CodecsRasterizeDocumentUnit
member.summary: Specifies the unit of a document page width, height or margins.

remarks.para: The is used to specify the unit of a document page width, height or margins. By using this enumeration, you can define document (logical) sizes in pixels, inches or millimeters.
The CodecsRasterizeDocumentUnit enumeration is used as the value for the following class members:

description.para: As the units for CodecsDocumentImageInfo.PageWidth and CodecsDocumentImageInfo.PageHeight

As the units for CodecsRasterizeDocumentLoadOptions.PageWidth, CodecsRasterizeDocumentLoadOptions.PageHeight, CodecsRasterizeDocumentLoadOptions.LeftMargin, CodecsRasterizeDocumentLoadOptions.TopMargin, CodecsRasterizeDocumentLoadOptions.RightMargin and CodecsRasterizeDocumentLoadOptions.BottomMargin

summary.para: The page width, height or margins are in pixels.
The page width, height or margins are in inches.
The page width, height or margins are in millimeters.

member.name: T:Leadtools.Codecs.CodecsRasterizeDocumentSizeMode
member.summary: Specifies the transformation to use when converting the logical size specified in the current document rasterization options to the final physical raster image size.

remarks.para: The enumeration type is used as the value for CodecsRasterizeDocumentLoadOptions.SizeMode property.

LEADTOOLS provides support for loading a document as a raster image. Document formats such as PDF, XPS, DOC/DOCX(2007/2010), PPT/PPTX(2007/2010), XLS/XLSX(2007/2010), RTF and Text do not contain physical width, height or resolution. It is up to the loader (in this case, the object) to specify the transformation from logical coordinates to physical pixels through a process called rasterization. For more information, refer to .

You can use the CodecsRasterizeDocumentLoadOptions.SizeMode property to control how to use CodecsRasterizeDocumentLoadOptions.PageWidth and CodecsRasterizeDocumentLoadOptions.PageHeight to control the final raster image size. LEADTOOLS will determine the original document size (a value that can be obtained in CodecsDocumentImageInfo.PageWidth and CodecsDocumentImageInfo.PageHeight and then apply the transformation from this value to determine the final width and height.

summary.para: Use the original document width and height. No transformation will be performed and CodecsRasterizeDocumentLoadOptions.PageWidth and CodecsRasterizeDocumentLoadOptions.PageHeight are not used.
The final will have a width or height value equals to the original document size.

Fit the resulting raster image into CodecsRasterizeDocumentLoadOptions.PageWidth and CodecsRasterizeDocumentLoadOptions.PageHeight while maintaining the aspect ratio. If the original document size is smaller than the requested page size, no transformation is performed.
The final will have a width or height equal to or less than the requested page width or height but not greater.

Always fit the resulting raster image into CodecsRasterizeDocumentLoadOptions.PageWidth and CodecsRasterizeDocumentLoadOptions.PageHeight while maintaining the aspect ratio. If the original document size is smaller than the requested page size, then the result image is scaled up.
The final will have a width or height equal to the requested page width or height. Not less and not greater.

Fit the resulting raster image width into CodecsRasterizeDocumentLoadOptions.PageWidth while maintaining the aspect ratio. The image height will be calculated based on the transformation and CodecsRasterizeDocumentLoadOptions.PageHeight is not used.
The final will have a width equal to the requested page width. The height depends on the original document height.

The resulting raster image width and height will be exactly equal to CodecsRasterizeDocumentLoadOptions.PageWidth and CodecsRasterizeDocumentLoadOptions.PageHeight. Aspect ratio might be different than the original document.
The final will have a width and height equal to the requested page width and height.

member.name: T:Leadtools.Codecs.CodecsDocumentImageInfo
member.summary: Provides information specific to document images.

remarks.para: LEADTOOLS provides support for loading a document as a raster image. Document formats such as PDF, XPS, DOC/DOCX(2007/2010), PPT/PPTX(2007/2010), XLS/XLSX(2007/2010), RTF and Text do not contain physical width, height or resolution. It is up to the loader (in this case, the object) to specify the transformation from logical coordinates to physical pixels through a process called rasterization. For more information, refer to .

description.para: true if the image file or stream passed to RasterCodecs.GetInformation or RasterCodecs.GetInformationAsync was a document file such as PDF or XPS and the other members of are valid. false, otherwise.
The original width of the document page in
The original height of the document page in
The unit for and

remarks.para: These values specify the original size of the document on disk regardless of the settings of current document rasterization. The CodecsImageInfo.Width, CodecsImageInfo.Height, CodecsImageInfo.XResolution and CodecsImageInfo.YResolution contains the size of the final rasterized document in physical units.
The original document format is returned as usual in CodecsImageInfo.Format.
The instance is returned in the CodecsImageInfo.Document property of the object returned by all the RasterCodecs.GetInformation or RasterCodecs.GetInformationAsync methods.

member.name: P:Leadtools.Codecs.CodecsDocumentImageInfo.IsDocumentFile
member.summary: Gets a value indicating whether the image file or stream is a document format.
member.value: true if the image file or stream is a document format, false; otherwise.

remarks.para: When the value of is true, then the image file or stream passed to the RasterCodecs.GetInformation or RasterCodecs.GetInformationAsync is a document file such as PDF or XPS. The rest of the members of this class are valid and contain the original document logical size. The physical load (rasterization size) is calculated based on the current rasterization values and is stored in CodecsImageInfo.Width, CodecsImageInfo.Height, CodecsImageInfo.XResolution and CodecsImageInfo.YResolution. For more information, refer to .
If the value of is false, then the image file or stream is a raster image such as JPEG or TIFF. These files have physical size and the rest of the values of this class should not be used.

member.name: P:Leadtools.Codecs.CodecsDocumentImageInfo.PageWidth
member.summary: Gets the logical width of the document.
member.value: A value that contains the logical width of the document. This value is in .

remarks.para: The logical width and height of the document is the original size before rasterization. LEADTOOLS usually returns the logical size in inches.
The , and properties are only valid if the value of is true.

remarks.para: The logical width and height of the document is the original size before rasterization. LEADTOOLS usually returns the logical size in inches.
The , and properties are only valid if the value of is true.
Possible values are:

description.para: The page width and height are in pixels

member.name: T:Leadtools.Codecs.CodecsPdfLoadOptions
member.summary: Provides options specifically for loading PDF, PS and EPS file options.

remarks.para: LEADTOOLS uses the same Leadtools.Pdf.dll assembly to load Adobe Portable Document Format (PDF), PostScript (PS) and Encapsulated PostScript (EPS) files.
PDF, PS and EPS files have no physical width or height in pixels. You can use the to control how the final document is rendered as a raster image. For more information, refer to .
To obtain extra information of a raster PDF file saved with , refer to .

java.pre: public class CodecsPdfLoadOptions

member.name: P:Leadtools.Codecs.CodecsPdfLoadOptions.HideNoApAnnotations
member.summary: Gets or sets a value that indicate whether to hide annotation objects that have no appearance stream.
member.value: true to hide annotation objects, false show annotation objects.

member.name: P:Leadtools.Codecs.CodecsPdfLoadOptions.HideAllAnnotations
member.summary: Gets or sets a value that indicate whether to hide all annotation objects.
member.value: true to hide all annotation objects, false show all annotation objects.

member.name: P:Leadtools.Codecs.CodecsPdfLoadOptions.UseLibFonts
member.summary: Gets a value that indicate whether to use the library installed fonts.
member.value: true to use the library installed fonts, false to use the system fonts. Default value is true.

remarks.para: The value of this property is used only when Leadtools.PdfEngine.dll is used by the application. For more information, refer to Implementing PDF Plug in Features.
This option affects the PDF format when UsePdfEngine is set to true to use Leadtools.PdfEngine.dll. It also affects the Postscript format.

java.pre: public boolean getUseLibFonts() public void setUseLibFonts(boolean value)

member.name: P:Leadtools.Codecs.CodecsPdfLoadOptions.DisplayDepth
member.summary: Gets or sets the resulting raster image pixel depth.
member.value: The resulting raster image pixel depth, valid values are 0, 1, 4, 8, or 24. The default value is 0 for auto-detect.
member.remarks:
Possible values are: ValueDescription
0Auto-detect. The resulting image will have the same bits per pixel as the requested page in the source PDF file. Internally, the toolkit will use the bits per pixel value of the first image item found on the page. If the page does not have any image items, the result will be 24 bits per pixel. Use this value only when the source file is a raster PDF.
11 bit per pixel in the resulting image.
44 bit per pixel in the resulting image.
88 bit per pixel in the resulting image.
2424 bit per pixel in the resulting image.
Refer to for information on how to use RasterCodecs.GetRasterPdfInfo to obtain this value from a PDF file saved with .
This option affect pdf format when UsePdfEngine is set to true to use Leadtools.PdfEngine.dll, it still affects Postscript format.

java.pre: public int getDisplayDepth() public void setDisplayDepth(int value)

member.name: P:Leadtools.Codecs.CodecsPdfLoadOptions.TextAlpha
member.summary: Gets or sets a value that indicate the type of font anti-aliasing to use.

value.para: The type of anti-aliasing to use. Default value is 1.

item.description: Do not use font anti-aliasing.
Use 2-bit font anti-aliasing.
Use 4-bit font anti-aliasing.

remarks.para: The value of this property is used only when the Leadtools.PdfEngine.dll is used by the application. For more information, refer to Implementing PDF Plug in Features.

Aliasing is the effect on all pixel devices where diagonal and curved lines have a zigzag appearance. As pixels get larger, this effect becomes more noticeable. Anti-aliasing refers to methods designed to decrease or eliminate this effect. Anti-aliasing is done by shading the pixels along the borders of the affected lines.
This affects the PDF format when UsePdfEngine is set to true to use Leadtools.PdfEngine.dll. It also affects the Postscript format.

java.pre: public int getTextAlpha() public void setTextAlpha(int value)

member.name: P:Leadtools.Codecs.CodecsPdfLoadOptions.GraphicsAlpha
member.summary: Gets or sets a value that indicate the type of graphics anti-aliasing to use.

value.para: The type of anti-aliasing to use. Default value is 1.

item.description: Do not use graphics anti-aliasing.
Use 2-bit graphics anti-aliasing.
Use 4-bit graphics anti-aliasing.

remarks.para: The value of this property is used only when Leadtools.PdfEngine.dll is used by the application. For more information, refer to Implementing PDF Plug in Features.

Aliasing is the effect on all pixel devices where diagonal and curved lines have a zigzag appearance. As pixels get larger, this effect becomes more noticeable. Anti-aliasing refers to methods designed to decrease or eliminate this effect. This is done by shading the pixels along the borders of the affected lines.
This option affect pdf format when UsePdfEngine is set to true to use Leadtools.PdfEngine.dll, it still affects Postscript format.

java.pre: public int getGraphicsAlpha() public void setGraphicsAlpha(int value)

member.name: P:Leadtools.Codecs.CodecsPdfLoadOptions.DisableCieColors
member.summary: Gets or sets a value that indicate whether CIE colors are disabled when loading PDF*, PS or EPS files.
member.value: true to disable the use of CIE colors, false otherwise. Default value is false.

remarks.para: The value of this property is used only when Leadtools.PdfEngine.dll is used by the application. For more information, refer to Implementing PDF Plug in Features.
Disabling the use of CIE colors will result in faster loading. This options is used when loading both PDF, PostScript (PS) and Encapsulated PostScript (EPS) files.
* This option affect pdf format when UsePdfEngine is set to true to use Leadtools.PdfEngine.dll, it still affects Postscript format.

java.pre: public boolean getDisableCieColors() public void setDisableCieColors(boolean value)

member.name: P:Leadtools.Codecs.CodecsPdfLoadOptions.EnableInterpolate
member.summary: Gets or sets a value that indicate whether to use interpolation when loading PDF*, PS or EPS files.
member.value: true to use interpolation when loading PDF, PS or EPS files, false otherwise. Default value is false.

remarks.para: The value of this property is used only when Leadtools.PdfEngine.dll is used by the application. For more information, refer to Implementing PDF Plug in Features.
Enabling the use of interpolation will result in slower loading but produces higher quality images. This options is used when loading PDF, PostScript (PS) and Encapsulated PostScript (EPS) files.
* This option affects the PDF format when UsePdfEngine is set to true to use Leadtools.PdfEngine.dll. It also affects the Postscript format.

java.pre: public boolean getEnableInterpolate() public void setEnableInterpolate(boolean value)

member.name: P:Leadtools.Codecs.CodecsPdfLoadOptions.UsePdfEngine
member.summary: Gets or sets a value to force using the LEADTOOLS PDF Engine (Leadtools.PdfEngine.dll) when loading PDF files.
member.value: true to force using the LEADTOOLS PDF Engine (Leadtools.PdfEngine.dll) when loading PDF files, otherwise; false. Default value is false.

remarks.para: To load or save PDF documents to/from a raster image in LEADTOOLS, you use the Leadtools.Pdf.dll assembly. This is the file filter for the PDF format (as well as Postscript and Enhanced Postscript). Use this assembly as any other file filter in LEADTOOLS, such as Leadtools.Codecs.Bmp.dll for BMP support and Leadtools.Codecs.Tif.dll for TIF support.
In addition to Leadtools.Pdf.dll, the Leadtools.PdfEngine.dll assembly is required in the following situations:

description.para: When loading Postscript (PS) or Enhanced Postscript (EPS) files. This is always needed regardless of the value of the UsePdfEngine option described below.

When using the LEADTOOLS DocumentReaders to read the objects of a PDF file (using the Leadtools.DocumentReaders.dll and Leadtools.DocumentReaders.Pdf.dll assemblies). Again, Leadtools.PdfEngine.dll is required regardless of the value of the UsePdfEngine option described below.

When the value of CodecsPdfLoadOptions.UsePdfEngine is set to true (the default value is false). When this option is used, then LEADTOOLS will use both Leadtools.Pdf.dll and Leadtools.PdfEngine.dll when loading PDF files. This is provided for legacy support.

remarks.para: Leadtools.PdfEngine.dll contains many resources such as tables and fonts required to render a PDF image (if one of the options above is satisfied and also always for PS and EPS files). This DLL is not referenced in a direct way by the file filter; instead it is loaded dynamically and out of a process if needed. You must ensure that this DLL is present on the machine. By default, it is required to have this DLL in the same directory where the file filter is located. However, to share many instances of the Leadtools.PdfEngine.dll assembly between many applications, use the CodecsPdfOptions.InitialPath property.

Note that if the application does not required PDF Engine, for example, the application is only loading and saving PDF files as raster images. Then, Leadtools.PdfEngine.dll is not required to be present on the machine. Leadtools.Pdf.dll is always required regardless. Leadtools.PdfEngine.dll is used out of process and may slow down loading PDF documents. It is recommended that you load PDF files with the set to false (the default value) for maximum performance.

member.name: T:Leadtools.Codecs.CodecsPdfOptions
member.summary: Provides extra options for loading and saving PDF images.

remarks.para: To load or save PDF documents to/from a raster image in LEADTOOLS, you use the Leadtools.Pdf.dll assembly. This is the file filter for the PDF format (as well as Postscript and Enhanced Postscript). Use this assembly as any other file filter in LEADTOOLS, such as Leadtools.Codecs.Bmp.dll for BMP support and Leadtools.Codecs.Tif.dll for TIF support.
In addition to Leadtools.Pdf.dll, the Leadtools.PdfEngine.dll assembly is required in the following situations:

description.para: When loading Postscript (PS) or Enhanced Postscript (EPS) files. This is always needed regardless of the value of the UsePdfEngine option described below.

When using the LEADTOOLS DocumentReaders to read the objects of a PDF file (using the Leadtools.DocumentReaders.dll and Leadtools.DocumentReaders.Pdf.dll assemblies). Again, Leadtools.PdfEngine.dll is required regardless of the value of the UsePdfEngine option described below.

When the value of CodecsPdfLoadOptions.UsePdfEngine is set to true (the default value is false). When this option is used, then LEADTOOLS will use both Leadtools.Pdf.dll and Leadtools.PdfEngine.dll when loading PDF files. This is provided for legacy support.

remarks.para: Leadtools.PdfEngine.dll contains many resources such as tables and fonts required to render a PDF image (if one of the options above is satisfied and also always for PS and EPS files). This DLL is not referenced in a direct way by the file filter; instead it is loaded dynamically and out of a process if needed. You must ensure that this DLL is present on the machine. By default, it is required to have this DLL in the same directory where the file filter is located. However, to share many instances of the Leadtools.PdfEngine.dll assembly between many applications, use the CodecsPdfOptions.InitialPath property.

Note that if the application does not required PDF Engine, for example, the application is only loading and saving PDF files as raster images. Then, Leadtools.PdfEngine.dll is not required to be present on the machine. Leadtools.Pdf.dll is always required regardless.

java.pre: public class CodecsPdfOptions

member.name: P:Leadtools.Codecs.CodecsPdfOptions.Load
member.summary: Gets the options for loading PDF images.
member.value: The PDF load options.

java.pre: public CodecsPdfLoadOptions getLoad()

member.name: P:Leadtools.Codecs.CodecsPdfOptions.Save
member.summary: Gets the options for saving PDF images.
member.value: The PDF save options.

java.pre: public CodecsPdfSaveOptions getSave()

member.name: P:Leadtools.Codecs.CodecsPdfOptions.InitialPath
member.summary: Gets and sets the path to the PDF engine runtime DLL.

remarks.para: The value of this property is used only when Leadtools.PdfEngine.dll is used by the application. For more information, refer to Implementing PDF Plug in Features.

The PDF engine runtime DLL is Leadtools.PdfEngine.dll. This DLL is never referenced directly by the LEADTOOLS Raster PDF file filter (Leadtools.Pdf.dll) or PDF document readers (Leadtools.DocumentReaders.Pdf) instead it is loaded dynamically and out of process by the filter.

By default, the LEADTOOLS installer will copy this DLL next to the filter (in the Bin\DotNet\Win32, Bin\DotNet\x64, Bin\DotNet4\Win32 and Bin\DotNet4\x64 folders) and the filter will look for the engine DLL in the same folder it is located (default location).

In some cases, you can share the same copy of Leadtools.PdfEngine.dll between different applications. For example, many ASP.NET web applications, in this case, you can copy Leadtools.PdfEngine.dll to a fixed directory on your server and pass the name of this directory to . From this point on, LEADTOOLS will use this value to locate and load Leadtools.PdfEngine.dll.

Leadtools.PdfEngine.dll is not a standard .NET assembly. In some project types, such as web applications or services, the compiler will not copy this file to your binary folder even though you have a reference to it in your project. This could cause PDF files to fail to load since IIS will create a temporary folder and copy all other LEADTOOLS referenced assemblies to service a request, but it will not copy Leadtools.PdfEngine.dll. So, when using PDF in a web application, you must always use to instruct LEADTOOLS on the location of the PDF engine DLL.

You do not have access to this property when using the LEADTOOLS WCF services to load PDF files, instead you must add a section in the web configuration to instruct the LEADTOOLS WCF service on the location of the PDF engine's DLL. Refer to Programming with LEADTOOLS WCF Services for more information.
Note that setting this value in a object will affect all the objects that are currently created in the application (in all threads) or will be created in the future, for example:

member.value: The path to the PDF runtime files, or an empty string or null (Nothing in Visual Basic), if the default location is to be used.

java.pre: public String getInitialPath() public void setInitialPath(String value)

member.name: P:Leadtools.Codecs.CodecsPdfOptions.IsEngineInstalled
member.summary: Determines whether or not the LEADTOOLS PDF Engine Runtime files are installed.
member.value: true if the LEADTOOLS PDF Engine Runtime files are installed, false if they are missing.

remarks.para: Use this property to determine if the LEADTOOLS PDF Engine Runtime files (Leadtools.PDfEngine.dll) are installed on the system.
The value of this property is used only when Leadtools.PdfEngine.dll is used by the application. For more information, refer to Implementing PDF Plug in Features.

java.pre: public boolean isEngineInstalled()

member.name: T:Leadtools.Codecs.CodecsLoadOptions
member.summary: Provides access to generic file load options.
member.seealso: Loading and Saving Large Tiff Files

java.pre: public class CodecsLoadOptions

member.name: M:Leadtools.Codecs.CodecsLoadOptions.Reset
member.summary: Resets this instance of to the default values.

java.pre: public void reset()

member.name: P:Leadtools.Codecs.CodecsLoadOptions.Markers
member.summary: Enables or disables loading metadata markers during image file load.
member.value: true to enable loading metadata markers if present in the file, false to ignore them.

remarks.para: When the value of the property is set to true, any subsequent load operation performed by this object will automatically try to load all the metadata (tags and comments) found in the file and store them in the RasterImage.Markers collection of the resulting image.
Note that any load method that uses tiles, offset or resizing will not load any file metadata automatically regardless of the value of this property.

java.pre: public boolean getMarkers() public void setMarkers(boolean value)

member.name: P:Leadtools.Codecs.CodecsLoadOptions.Tags
member.summary: Gets or sets a value that indicates whether any tags found in the file should be automatically loaded.
member.value: true to automatically load any tags found in the file; otherwise it is false.

remarks.para: When the value of the property is set to true, any subsequent load operation performed by this object will automatically try to load all the tags found in the file and store them in the RasterImage.Tags collection of the resulting image.
Internally, the object will call on the image and only tries to load the tags if the value returned was true.

When loading more than one page from a multi-page file, only the tags found in the first page will be automatically loaded when the value of this property is set to true. To manually load all the tags in any page, use .

You must set the value of the property to false to enable automatically loading the tags. If the value of both and is set to true, then the markers will take take precedence and no tags will be loaded.
Note that any load method that uses tiles, offset or resizing will not load any file metadata automatically regardless of the value of this property.

example.para: This example will browse to a file and load it along with any tags, geo-keys and comments found.

java.pre: public boolean getTags() public void setTags(boolean value)

member.name: P:Leadtools.Codecs.CodecsLoadOptions.GeoKeys
member.summary: Gets or sets a value that indicates whether any TIFF Geo key tags found in the file should be automatically loaded.
member.value: true to automatically load any TIFF Geo key tags found in the file, otherwise; false.

remarks.para: When the value of the property is set to true, any subsequent load operation performed by this object will automatically try to load all the TIFF Geo key tags found in the file and store them in the RasterImage.GeoKeys collection of the resulting image.
Internally, the object will call on the image and only tries to load the GeoKeys if the value returned was true.

When loading more than one page from a multi-page file, only the GeoKeys found in the first page will be automatically loaded when the value of this property is set to true. To manually load all the GeoKeys in any page, use .

You must set the value of the property to false to enable automatically loading the GeoKeys. If the value of both and is set to true, then the markers will take take precedence and no GeoKeys will be loaded.
Note that any load method that uses tiles, offset or resizing will not load any file metadata automatically regardless of the value of this property.

java.pre: public boolean getGeoKeys() public void setGeoKeys(boolean value)

member.name: P:Leadtools.Codecs.CodecsLoadOptions.Comments
member.summary: Gets or sets a value that indicate whether any comment fields found in the file should be automatically loaded.
member.value: true to automatically load any comment fields found in the file; otherwise it is false.

remarks.para: When the value of the property is set to true, any subsequent load operation performed by this object will automatically try to load all the comment fields found in the file and store them in the RasterImage.Comments collection of the resulting image.
Internally, the object will call on the image and only try to load the comments if the value returned is true.

When loading more than one page from a multi-page file, only the comments found in the first page will be automatically loaded when the value of this property is set to true. To manually load all the comments in any page, use .

You must set the value of the property to false to enable automatic loading the comments. If the value of both and is set to true, the markers will take take precedence and no comments will be loaded.
Note that any load method that uses tiles, offset or resizing will not load any file metadata automatically regardless of the value of this property.

java.pre: public boolean getComments() public void setComments(boolean value)

member.name: P:Leadtools.Codecs.CodecsLoadOptions.AllocateImage
member.summary: Enables or disables the allocation of memory for the storage of the image data.
member.value: true to have Leadtools do the necessary allocation, false to disable it.
member.remarks: If you do not allow Leadtools to allocate the memory for the storage of the image data, then you should process the data manually using the RasterCodecs.LoadImage event.

java.pre: public boolean getAllocateImage() public void setAllocateImage(boolean value)

member.name: P:Leadtools.Codecs.CodecsLoadOptions.StoreDataInImage
member.summary: Enables or disables the automatic storage of the image data into the during a file load process.
member.value: true to have Leadtools store the loaded image data into the , false to disable it.
member.remarks: If you do not allow Leadtools to allocate the memory for the storage of the image data, then you should process the data manually using the RasterCodecs.LoadImage event.

java.pre: public boolean getStoreDataInImage() public void setStoreDataInImage(boolean value)

member.name: P:Leadtools.Codecs.CodecsLoadOptions.Format
member.summary: Gets or sets the load format.
member.value: A enumeration value that specifies the load format.
member.remarks: By default, the value of this property is set to false. This means that the object should try and recognize the format of the image its trying to load itself. If you know the format of the file, pass it to this member prior to calling RasterCodecs.Load or RasterCodecs.LoadAsync, this will skip the format recognition process and speed up the load operation.

java.pre: public RasterImageFormat getFormat() public void setFormat(RasterImageFormat value)

member.name: P:Leadtools.Codecs.CodecsLoadOptions.XResolution
member.summary: Gets or sets the horizontal resolution (DPI).
member.value: The horizontal resolution (DPI).
member.remarks: Use this property to set the X resolution member of the RasterImage when the file format being loaded either does not support resolution or the file has no value stored.

java.pre: public int getXResolution() public void setXResolution(int value)

member.name: P:Leadtools.Codecs.CodecsLoadOptions.YResolution
member.summary: Gets or sets the vertical resolution (DPI).
member.value: The vertical resolution (DPI).
member.remarks: Use this property to set the Y resolution member of the RasterImage when the file format being loaded either does not support resolution or the file has no value stored.

java.pre: public int getYResolution() public void setYResolution(int value)

member.name: P:Leadtools.Codecs.CodecsLoadOptions.Passes
member.summary: Gets or sets the number of passes (scans through the image) when loading a progressive image (JPEG mainly).

value.para: The number of passes (scans through the image) when loading a progressive image.

item.description: Load a progressive file showing at most the specified number of passes.
Load the file in one pass.
Load a progressive file showing only significant scans.
Load a progressive file showing all the scans.

remarks.para: This value is also used when loading JBIG files to determine the number of resolutions to load to create a progressive load effect.

This property controls the number of times the RasterCodecs.LoadImage event can be called for a particular row. If you do not use the RasterCodecs.LoadImage event, this value is ignored.The RasterCodecs.LoadImage event can be used to implement a paint while load feature. For progressive files, the event is called several times for the same image row. The quality of the row is improved with every call. The improvements in some passes do not have visual improvements, so it is recommended you show only the significant scans (-1).

java.pre: public int getPasses() public void setPasses(int value)

member.name: P:Leadtools.Codecs.CodecsLoadOptions.Rotated
member.summary: Indicates whether or not to load files without rotating them.
member.value: true to load files rotated, false to ignore the view perspective stored in the file.
member.remarks: This affects files that can be saved with a rotated view perspective.

java.pre: public boolean getRotated() public void setRotated(boolean value)

member.name: P:Leadtools.Codecs.CodecsLoadOptions.Signed
member.summary: Indicates whether or not to load the image with negative pixel values.
member.value: true to load and keep negative pixel values, false to set negative pixel values to 0.

java.pre: public boolean getSigned() public void setSigned(boolean value)

member.name: P:Leadtools.Codecs.CodecsLoadOptions.InitAlpha
member.summary: Indicates whether or not to initialize the alpha channel when loading images as 32 or 64-bit.
member.value: true to set the alpha channel to ones (0xFF for 8-bit and OxFFFF for 16-bit), false to set the alpha channel to zeros.

remarks.para: The default value for this property has changed from false to true in LEADTOOLS v16.5.

java.pre: public boolean getInitAlpha() public void setInitAlpha(boolean value)

member.name: P:Leadtools.Codecs.CodecsLoadOptions.UseWriteableBitmap
member.summary: Indicates whether or not to use a Silverlight WriteableBitmap object for storing the image data.
member.value: true to use a Silverlight WriteableBitmap object for storing the image data; false otherwise.

remarks.para: This property is only supported in Silverlight versions of LEADTOOLS.
Setting this property to true can speed up image loading, image processing and image display by using a Silverlight WriteableBitmap object for storing the image data.
Setting this property to true will force the image data to be loaded as 32-bit, and will ignore the bitsPerPixel parameter passed to RasterCodecs.Load.

member.name: P:Leadtools.Codecs.CodecsLoadOptions.AutoDetectAlpha
member.summary: Indicates whether or not to automatically detect if the image has meaningful alpha channel values.
member.value: true automatically detect if the image has meaningful alpha channel values; false otherwise.

remarks.para: This property is only supported in Silverlight versions of LEADTOOLS.
This property only has an effect when using a Silverlight WriteableBitmap object for image data storage.

Setting this property to true can slow down image loading and image processing. If you know that your images have meaningful alpha channel values or if you know that your images have only 0xFF for alpha channel values, set this property to false.
When this property is true, LEADTOOLS will detect if the loaded image data contains meaningful alpha channel values and then set the RasterImage.PremultiplyAlpha property accordingly.

java.pre: public boolean getAutoDetectAlpha() public void setAutoDetectAlpha(boolean value)

member.name: P:Leadtools.Codecs.CodecsLoadOptions.UseNativeLoad
member.summary: Indicates whether or not to use the native image load capabilities of Silverlight.
member.value: true to use the native image load capabilities of Silverlight; false otherwise.

remarks.para: NOTE: This property is only supported in Silverlight versions of LEADTOOLS.
When using this property, if the input image is of a format that is supported natively by Silverlight, then LEADTOOLS will use the native image load capabilities to decode the data.
Setting this property to true will speed up image load times for natively supported file formats.
If the input file is not a format natively supported by Silverlight, then the LEADTOOLS codecs will decode the file.

When this property is true and the file is a format natively supported by Silverlight, the resulting image data will be stored in a Silverlight WriteableBitmap. For more information, see CodecsLoadOptions.UseWriteableBitmap and RasterImage.IsGlobalMemory.

java.pre: public boolean getUseNativeLoad() public void setUseNativeLoad(boolean value)

member.name: P:Leadtools.Codecs.CodecsLoadOptions.FixedPalette
member.summary: Enables or disables loading the image to the LEAD fixed palette.
member.value: true to force a palletized image to be dithered to the LEAD fixed palette.

java.pre: public boolean getFixedPalette() public void setFixedPalette(boolean value)

member.name: P:Leadtools.Codecs.CodecsLoadOptions.NoInterlace
member.summary: Enables or disables loading files as interlaced.
member.value: When set to true, the Load methods pass image data in the order that is displayed, regardless of how it is stored in the file.
member.remarks: Set this flag if your program does not handle interlaced file formats.

java.pre: public boolean getNoInterlace() public void setNoInterlace(boolean value)

member.name: P:Leadtools.Codecs.CodecsLoadOptions.Compressed
member.summary: Enables or disables keeping the loaded image data compressed in memory.
member.value: true to keep loaded data compressed in memory.
member.remarks: If possible, load the file as a 1-bit RLE-compressed image. Note: This requires Document and Medical Support.

java.pre: public boolean getCompressed() public void setCompressed(boolean value)

member.name: P:Leadtools.Codecs.CodecsLoadOptions.SuperCompressed
member.summary: Enables or disables keeping the loaded image data compressed in memory.
member.value: true to keep loaded data compressed in memory.
member.remarks: If possible, load the file as a 24-bit LEAD Super-compressed image. Note: This requires Document and Medical Support.

java.pre: public boolean getSuperCompressed() public void setSuperCompressed(boolean value)

member.name: P:Leadtools.Codecs.CodecsLoadOptions.TiledMemory
member.summary: Gets or sets a value indicating whether to use tiled memory when loading an image.
member.value: true to load the image using tiled; false otherwise.
member.remarks: When the value of this property is true, the image is created where the data pointers are maintained in tiles, useful for very large images.
member.example: For an example on changing the default load memory mode, refer to .

java.pre: public boolean getTiledMemory() public void setTiledMemory(boolean value)

member.name: P:Leadtools.Codecs.CodecsLoadOptions.NoTiledMemory
member.summary: Gets or sets a value indicating whether to allow tiled images.
member.value: true to prevent tiled image; false otherwise.
member.remarks: When using tiled memory, the image is created where the data pointers are maintained in tiles, useful for very large images. Setting the value of this property to true will prevent the image from being created in tiles.
member.example: For an example on changing the default load memory mode, refer to .

java.pre: public boolean getNoTiledMemory() public void setNoTiledMemory(boolean value)

member.name: P:Leadtools.Codecs.CodecsLoadOptions.DiskMemory
member.summary: Gets or sets a value indicating whether to use disk memory when loading an image.
member.value: true to load the image using disk memory; false otherwise.
member.remarks: When the value of this property is true, the image is stored in disk and not in conventional memory.

java.pre: public boolean getDiskMemory() public void setDiskMemory(boolean value)

member.name: P:Leadtools.Codecs.CodecsLoadOptions.NoDiskMemory
member.summary: Gets or sets a value indicating whether to allow disk memory when loading an image.
member.value: true to prevent loading the image using disk memory; false otherwise.
member.remarks: When using tiled memory, the image data is stored in disk and not in conventional memory. Setting the value of this property to true will prevent the image from being created in disk.
member.example: For an example on changing the default load memory mode, refer to .

java.pre: public boolean getNoDiskMemory() public void setNoDiskMemory(boolean value)

member.name: P:Leadtools.Codecs.CodecsLoadOptions.LoadCorrupted
member.summary: Indicates whether or not to load corrupted files without throwing an exception.
member.value: true to load corrupted files, false to throw an exception if the file cannot be completely loaded successfully.
member.remarks: This mainly applies to JPEG compressed files that have corruption in the compressed data. If this property is set to True, then LEADTOOLS will load as much of the image data as possible, and will not throw an exception.

java.pre: public boolean getLoadCorrupted() public void setLoadCorrupted(boolean value)

member.name: M:Leadtools.Codecs.CodecsSaveOptions.GetResolutions
member.summary: Gets the resolutions to save when saving multi-resolution files.
member.returns: An array of structures indicating the resolutions to save.

remarks.para: Currently, this only works with the JBIG format.
For JBIG, the maximum number of resolutions that can be saved is 29.
For a JBIG file, the values of different resolutions are implied because the dimensions of each resolution layer are half the dimensions of the one directly above it.

and are used to determine the highest resolution layer which will be saved in a file. You can fill the array with an actual width and height, or you can fill either the width or height with a valid value, and specify 0 for the other dimension to allow LEADTOOLS to calculate that dimension based on the image's aspect ratio during the next save operation. Note that for JBIG, all the values set in the array are stored, but only the first item is used during an actual file save process.
Ex.
If you then save an image that is 1600 x 1200, the resolutions that are stored in the file would be:

java.pre: public LeadSize[] getResolutions()

member.name: M:Leadtools.Codecs.CodecsSaveOptions.SetResolutions(Leadtools.LeadSize[])
member.summary: Sets the resolutions to save when saving multi-resolution files.
member.param: An array of structures indicating the resolutions to save.

remarks.para: Currently, this only works with the JBIG format.
For JBIG, the maximum number of resolutions that can be saved is 29.
For a JBIG file, the values of different resolutions are implied because the dimensions of each resolution layer are half the dimensions of the one directly above it.

and are used to determine the highest resolution layer which will be saved in a file. You can fill the array with an actual width and height, or you can fill either the width or height with a valid value, and specify 0 for the other dimension to allow LEADTOOLS to calculate that dimension based on the image's aspect ratio during the next save operation. Note that for JBIG, all the values set in the array are stored, but only the first item is used during an actual file save process.
Ex.
If you then save an image that is 1600 x 1200, the resolutions that are stored in the file would be:

java.pre: public void setResolutions(LeadSize[] resolutions)

member.name: P:Leadtools.Codecs.CodecsSaveOptions.RetrieveDataFromImage
member.summary: Gets or sets a value that indicate whether to automatically populate the scanline buffers in when using the RasterCodecs.SaveImage event.
member.value: true to automatically populate the scanline buffers in when using the RasterCodecs.SaveImage event, or false to make the user responsible for populating the scanline buffers. Default value is false.

remarks.para: The property works as the input and output buffer containing the image data to save. If the value of is set to false (the default), then the user is always responsible for providing the image data by setting in . If the value of is set to true, then the object will populate the prior to raising this event. The user can then inspect or modify the scanlines data or simple ignore it to save the original image data as is.

Notice that on either case, the user must provide the scanline data in the source image original format (stored in the property. The object will then convert this data to the appropriate output format if needed, for example, if the user instructed the object to save the image in a different file format than the original image.

example.para: The following example shows how to use to:

item.description: Save the image without instructing to automatically populate the data. Resulting in an output file with a blank image.
Save the image while to automatically populate the data. Resulting in a correct output image.
Save the image with automatically generating the data then manipulating it to generate an output file that is an invert of the original image.

java.pre: public boolean getRetrieveDataFromImage() public void setRetrieveDataFromImage(boolean value)

member.name: P:Leadtools.Codecs.CodecsOptions.RasterizeDocument
member.summary: Gets the options used when loading or saving a document file.
member.value: An instance of object that contains the current document file load and save options.

remarks.para: LEADTOOLS provides support for loading a document as a raster image. Document formats such as PDF, XPS, DOC/DOCX(2007/2010), PPT/PPTX(2007/2010), XLS/XLSX(2007/2010), RTF and Text do not contain physical width, height or resolution. It is up to the loader (in this case, the object) to specify the transformation from logical coordinates to physical pixels through a process called rasterization. For more information, refer to .

member.name: P:Leadtools.Codecs.CodecsOptions.Vector
member.summary: Gets the options used when loading or saving a vector image file.
member.value: An instance of object that contains the current vector image file load and save options.
member.para: LEADTOOLS provides support for loading a vector image as a raster image. Vector formats such as DXF, DWG and SVG can be converted to a raster image through a process called rasterization.

member.name: P:Leadtools.Codecs.CodecsSaveImageEventArgs.PagePercent
member.summary: Gets the save completion percentage of the current page.
member.value: A number between 0 and 100 that indicates the completion percentage of the save operation of the current page.

remarks.para: Using the and properties, you can use the to show a progress bar of the current save operation.

When saving a multi-page file, will go from 0 to 100 for each page saved while will go from 0 to 100 only once during the whole page operation. Usually, you will use to show an overall save progress if the multi-page image is considered to be one document. If however, individual progress is required for each page, then you can track the property as well.
When saving a single page file or one page to a multi-page file, both and will go from 0 to 100 simultaneously.

member.example: For an example, refer to RasterCodecs.SaveImage.

java.pre: public int getPagePercent()

member.value: A number between 0 and 100 that indicates the overall completion percentage of the save operation.

When saving a single page file or one page to a multi-page file, both and will go from 0 to 100 simultaneously.

member.name: T:Leadtools.Codecs.CodecsCmpQualityFactorPredefined
member.summary: Indicates the pre-defined quality factor for saving LEAD CMP compressed images.
member.seealso: Compression Using LEAD and JPEG Formats

java.pre: public enum CodecsCmpQualityFactorPredefined

summary.para: Perfect quality 1
This option compresses all colors of a 24-bit file and maintains the quality of the original image at a smaller file size. As the name suggests, there is no visual loss of color at this setting.
Perfect quality 2
This will produce a smaller file size than PQ1 while maintaining similar quality.
Quality far more important than size
This option removes colors not noticed by the human eye. Most viewers cannot tell the difference between an image compressed at this level and the original image.
Quality more important than size

While more colors are removed, most of them are colors or shades that are close to one another. The compressed image will appear very much like the original image. It will take some study to see the difference.
Quality and size equally important

This option provides the highest compression while maintaining good image quality. Try this option first, then move up or down the list accordingly to obtain acceptable compression size and image quality.
Size more important that quality (sharp)

This option is recommended for images that have sharp edges. For example, an image that has a text overlay or an image with many straight lines. While it creates a larger file than the next option, it retains better edges.
Size more important than quality (less tiling)
This option produces less tiling in the image than the previous options. However, it may distort some text or straight lines. It is a good option for image database applications.
Maximum compression keeping quality
This option provides maximum compression while maintaining as high as possible image quality.
Maximum compression
This option gives maximum compression. It is equivalent to a Q factor of 255.
Custom Quality Factor.

member.name: T:Leadtools.Codecs.CodecsJpeg2000ProgressionsOrder
member.summary: Indicates the order of progression.

java.pre: public enum CodecsJpeg2000ProgressionsOrder

member.name: F:Leadtools.Codecs.CodecsJpeg2000ProgressionsOrder.LayerResolutionComponentPosition
member.summary: Quality axis order. Image starts out blurry and becomes clearer and more detailed as additional data is decoded.

member.name: F:Leadtools.Codecs.CodecsJpeg2000ProgressionsOrder.ResolutionLayerComponentPosition
member.summary: Resolution-axis order. Image starts out small and becomes larger as additional data is decoded. Higher compression ratios achieved by leaving lower resolutions in the file.

member.name: F:Leadtools.Codecs.CodecsJpeg2000ProgressionsOrder.ResolutionPositionComponentLayer
member.summary: Resolution-axis order. Image starts out small and becomes larger as additional data is decoded. Higher compression ratios achieved by leaving lower resolutions in the file.

member.name: F:Leadtools.Codecs.CodecsJpeg2000ProgressionsOrder.PositionComponentResolutionLayer
member.summary: Position axis order. Image starts out as a series of blocks starting from the top left corner. Additional portions of the image become visible as more data is decoded. Image data stored by spatial location.

member.name: F:Leadtools.Codecs.CodecsJpeg2000ProgressionsOrder.ComponentPositionResolutionLayer
member.summary: Color-axis order. Image starts out gray. Color is added as more data is decoded. Image data stored by color channel, starting with channel Y, then U, then V. If the transform to YUV option is used, the lowest decompressed image level for RGB is grayscale. Otherwise, the output is only the red channel.

member.summary: Use the region stored in the .

member.name: T:Leadtools.Codecs.CodecsJpeg2000PrecinctSize
member.summary: Values to specify the size of JPEG 2000 compressed packets, provides a mean of random access into a JPEG 2000 compressed stream.
member.remarks:
Precincts are rectangular regions in the wavelet domain, within a given resolution level and image component that represent a spatial region on the image. They are used for limiting the size of JPEG 2000 compressed packets and to provide a means of random access into a JPEG 2000 compressed stream. For this reason, they should be used for interactive transfer of JPEG 2000 files as in JPIP applications. In general, dividing the image into precincts is better than tiling it. So it is recommended that users compress the image as one tile and use precincts to divide the spatial region. This will give better compression ratios and image quality.
Using smaller precinct dimensions provides finer access to the compressed stream yet increases the compressed stream size. It is recommended to use HierarchicalOne128 and no tiling to generate JPEG 2000 files for any purpose.

java.pre: public enum CodecsJpeg2000PrecinctSize

member.name: F:Leadtools.Codecs.CodecsJpeg2000PrecinctSize.Full
member.summary: No precinct is used, size is infinite.

member.name: F:Leadtools.Codecs.CodecsJpeg2000PrecinctSize.Uniform64
member.summary: For all resolution levels, a precinct dimension of [64x64] will be applied.

member.name: F:Leadtools.Codecs.CodecsJpeg2000PrecinctSize.Uniform128
member.summary: For all resolution levels, a precinct dimension of [128x128] will be applied.

member.name: F:Leadtools.Codecs.CodecsJpeg2000PrecinctSize.Uniform256
member.summary: For all resolution levels, a precinct dimension of [256x256] will be applied.

member.name: F:Leadtools.Codecs.CodecsJpeg2000PrecinctSize.Uniform512
member.summary: For all resolution levels, a precinct dimension of [512x512] will be applied.

member.name: F:Leadtools.Codecs.CodecsJpeg2000PrecinctSize.Uniform1024
member.summary: For all resolution levels, a precinct dimension of [1024x1024] will be applied.

member.name: F:Leadtools.Codecs.CodecsJpeg2000PrecinctSize.Uniform2048
member.summary: For all resolution levels, a precinct dimension of [2048x2048] will be applied.

member.name: F:Leadtools.Codecs.CodecsJpeg2000PrecinctSize.HierarchicalOne64
member.summary:
A precinct size of [X by X] will be applied to the first(smallest) resolution of the image. The second resolution precinct dimension would be [2X by 2X]. The third resolution precinct dimension would be [4X by 4X] and so on. If the JPEG 2000 file has five levels and HierarchicalOne64 is used, the precinct dimensions will be as follows:
[64x64] level 1
[128x128] level 2
[256x256] level 3
[512x512] level 4
[1024x1024] level 5

member.name: F:Leadtools.Codecs.CodecsJpeg2000PrecinctSize.HierarchicalOne128
member.summary:
A precinct size of [X by X] will be applied to the first(smallest) resolution of the image. The second resolution precinct dimension would be [2X by 2X]. The third resolution precinct dimension would be [4X by 4X] and so on. If the JPEG 2000 file has five levels and HierarchicalOne128 is used, the precinct dimensions will be as follows:
[128x128] level 1
[256x256]level 2
[512x512]level 3
[1024x1024] level 4
[2048x2048] level 5

member.name: F:Leadtools.Codecs.CodecsJpeg2000PrecinctSize.HierarchicalOne256
member.summary:
A precinct size of [X by X] will be applied to the first(smallest) resolution of the image. The second resolution precinct dimension would be [2X by 2X]. The third resolution precinct dimension would be [4X by 4X] and so on. If the JPEG 2000 file has five levels and HierarchicalOne256 is used, the precinct dimensions will be as follows:
[256x256] level 1
[512x512] level 2
[1024x1024] level 3
[2048x2048] level 4
[4096x4096] level 5

member.name: F:Leadtools.Codecs.CodecsJpeg2000PrecinctSize.HierarchicalOne512
member.summary:
A precinct size of [X by X] will be applied to the first(smallest) resolution of the image. The second resolution precinct dimension would be [2X by 2X]. The third resolution precinct dimension would be [4X by 4X] and so on. If the JPEG 2000 file has five levels and HierarchicalOne512 is used, the precinct dimensions will be as follows:
[512x512] level 1
[1024x1024 level 2
[2048x2048] level 3
[4096x4096]level 4
[8192x8192] level 5

member.name: F:Leadtools.Codecs.CodecsJpeg2000PrecinctSize.HierarchicalTwo64
member.summary:
A precinct size of [X by X] will be applied to the first and second (smallest) resolutions of the image. The third and fourth resolution precinct dimensions would be [2X by 2X] and so on. So if the JPEG 2000 file has five levels and HierarchicalTwo64 is used, the precinct dimensions will be as follows:
[64x64] level 1
[64x64] level 2
[128x128] level 3
[128x128] level 4
[256x256] level 5

member.name: F:Leadtools.Codecs.CodecsJpeg2000PrecinctSize.HierarchicalTwo128

member.summary:

member.name: P:Leadtools.Codecs.CodecsJpeg2000SaveOptions.DecompositionLevels
member.summary: Gets or sets the number of resolution levels in the compressed file.
member.value: The number of resolution levels in the compressed file.
member.remarks: The maximum number of levels depends on the size of the image. Passing values that are too large will cause the save operation to fail. Each resolution level is one-half the size of the previous resolution, in both dimensions (width and height), starting with the full image resolution. The resolutions are not stored independently, and do not have a major impact on the compression results. The default value is 5, which produces the best compression ratios in most cases.

java.pre: public int getDecompositionLevels() public void setDecompositionLevels(int value)

member.name: P:Leadtools.Codecs.CodecsJpeg2000SaveOptions.UseSopMarker
member.summary: Enables or disables use of the Start of Packet(SOP) marker.
member.value: true to use the SOP marker; false, otherwise.
member.remarks: The "Start of Packet" and "End of Packet Header" markers help detect file corruption during transmission. If these markers exist in the JPEG2000 compressed stream, it is easy for the decoder to find the packet boundary, or, in case of a stream error, check the size. If UseSopMarker is true, each packet in any given tile part will be prepended with a SOP marker segment. The SOP marker includes the size of the packet. The default value is false.

java.pre: public boolean getUseSopMarker() public void setUseSopMarker(boolean value)

member.name: P:Leadtools.Codecs.CodecsJpeg2000SaveOptions.UseEphMarker
member.summary: Enables or disables use of the End of Packet Header (EPH) marker.
member.value: true to use the EPH marker; false, otherwise.
member.remarks: The "Start of Packet" and "End of Packet Header" markers help detect file corruption during transmission. If these markers exist in the JPEG2000 compressed stream, it is easy for the decoder to find the packet boundary, or, in case of a stream error, check the size. If UseEphMarker is true, each packet header in any given tile part is postpended with an EPH marker segment. The default value is false.

java.pre: public boolean getUseEphMarker() public void setUseEphMarker(boolean value)

member.name: P:Leadtools.Codecs.CodecsJpeg2000SaveOptions.AlphaChannelActiveBits
member.summary: Gets or sets a value indicating the active bits for the alpha channel.
member.value: The active bits for the alpha channel. Possible values are 1 and 8. If the value is 1 it means the 256 levels of the 8-bit alpha channels will be transformed into two levels of value 255 or 0, using simple threshold. The threshold value is 127, so all values gt; 127 will be set to 255 and all values lt;= 127 will be set to 0. If the value is 8, all 256 levels of the 8-bit alpha channels will be compressed. This is the default value. This option should be used on a 32-bit bitmap: otherwise, it has no effect.

java.pre: public int getAlphaChannelActiveBits() public void setAlphaChannelActiveBits(int value)

member.name: P:Leadtools.Codecs.CodecsJpeg2000SaveOptions.AlphaChannelLossless
member.summary: Gets or sets a value indicating whether to save the alpha channel as lossless.
member.value: true to save the alpha channel as lossless; false, otherwise.
member.remarks: The default value is true. The resulting image is 32-bit. The value of this property controls the compression type of alpha channel for J2K/JP2 lossy compression. This option should be used on a 32-bit bitmap otherwise it has no effect.

java.pre: public boolean getAlphaChannelLossless() public void setAlphaChannelLossless(boolean value)

member.name: T:Leadtools.Codecs.CodecsJpeg2000Options
member.summary: Provides extra options for loading and saving JPEG 2000 and LEAD CMW images.

remarks.p: The JPEG2000 image format offers both superior compression performance and robust file handling. Some J2K options can have a direct impact on compression performance, while others primarily affect resulting file size. Notes on Advanced options continue below.
Main options (listed above) include:

li.p: Random codestream access and processing (Progression Order)
Error resilience for transmission in noisy environments, such as wireless and the Internet.

strong.p: Using this structure with LEAD CMW (Cmw) or TIFF with LEAD Wavelet CMW compression (TifCmw) files

remarks.p: When using this structure with Cmw or TifCmw files, only the following data properties are required:

The resulting file size/ compression ratio can be determined in several ways. Depending on the value set in the CompressionControl property, the user can set the size of the target file, the actual compression ratio to use during compression or the quality factor to use during compression. If the property is set to Ratio, then the compression used is based on the compression ratio in the property. If the property is set to TargetSize, the compression used is based on the desired target file size in the property. If the property is set to QualityFactor, then the compression used is based on the QualityFactor passed to the Save functions.
For lossless compression, set the property to Lossless.
There are two types of quantization for Lossy compression: Scalar Derived Quantization and Scalar Expounded Quantization.

The exponent/mantissa pairs are either signaled in the codestream for every sub-band (expounded quantization) or else signaled only for the Low Pass sub-band and derived for all other sub-bands (derived quantization). In the case of derived quantization, all exponent/mantissa pairs are derived from the single exponent/mantissa pair corresponding to the Low pass sub-band.
The quantization step size for a sub-band is calculated from the dynamic range of the sub-band using the following equation, where R = bpp for the sub-band:

If the value of the property is Ratio, QualityFactor or TargetSize, and the value of the property is true, the compressed J2K/JP2 file will have three lossy components (red, green and blue), in addition to the lossless alpha component.
If the value of the property is Lossless, the value of will be ignored and all the components will be lossless.
The alpha channel can be dithered using and externally, and before saving a J2K/JP2 file, in case a better alpha channel quality is desired.

The values of the , , , , and properties are used to create tiles within the image. Arbitrary tile sizes are allowed. All tiles are the same size, except for the border tiles. Each tile can be compressed individually. This can decrease memory usage while the program is running, but can also generate artifacts at the edges of the tiles. Artifacts generally increase as the size of the tile decreases. By default, there is one tile that contains the entire image.

The reference grid is a rectangular grid of points with the indices from (0, 0) to (Xsiz-1, Ysiz-1). An "image area" is defined on the reference grid by the dimensional parameters, (Xsiz, Ysiz) and (XOsiz, YOsiz). The various parameters defining the reference grid appear in the figures below.

Specifically, the image area on the reference grid is defined by its upper left hand reference grid point at location (XOsiz, YOsiz), and its lower right hand reference grid point at location (Xsiz-1, Ysiz-1).

item.description: XOsiz
YOsiz
XTsiz
YTsiz
XTOsiz
YTOsiz

remarks.p: For a given tile-part, the packets contain all compressed image data from a specific layer, a specific component, a specific resolution level, and a specific precinct. The order in which these packets are found in the codestream is called the progression order. Use the property to set the progression order. The ProgressingOrder property uses the enumeration to specify the progression The ordering of the packets can progress along four axes: layer, component, resolution and position. The following progressions can be specified:

li.p: LayerResolutionComponentPosition. A progression of this type might be useful when low sample accuracy is most desirable, but information is needed for all components.
ResolutionLayerComponentPosition. A progression of this type might be useful in providing low-resolution level versions of all image components.
ResolutionPositionComponentLayer. A progression of this type might be useful in providing low-resolution level versions of all image components at a particular spatial location.
PositionComponentResolutionLayer. A progression of this type might be useful in providing high sample accuracy for a particular spatial location in all components.
ComponentPositionResolutionLayer. A progression of this type might be useful in providing high accuracy for a particular spatial location in a particular image component.

remarks.p: For more information, refer to:

p.a: ISO/IEC JTC1/SC29/WG1 N1861: Coding of Still Pictures

member.name: T:Leadtools.Codecs.CodecsVectorImageInfo
member.summary: Provides information specific to vector images.

remarks.para: LEADTOOLS provides support for loading a vector image as a raster image. Vector formats such as DXF, DWG and SVG can be converted to a raster image through a process called rasterization.

member.name: P:Leadtools.Codecs.CodecsVectorImageInfo.IsVectorFile
member.summary: Gets a value indicating whether the image file or stream is a vector image format.
member.value: true if the image file or stream is a vector image format, false; otherwise.

remarks.para: When the value of is true, then the image file or stream passed to the RasterCodecs.GetInformation or RasterCodecs.GetInformationAsync is a vector image file such as DXF or DWG. The rest of the members of this class are valid and contain the original document logical size. The physical load (rasterization size) is calculated based on the current rasterization values and is stored in CodecsImageInfo.Width, CodecsImageInfo.Height, CodecsImageInfo.XResolution and CodecsImageInfo.YResolution. For more information, refer to .
If the value of is false, then the image file or stream is a raster image such as JPEG or TIFF. These files have physical size and the rest of the values of this class should not be used.

member.name: M:Leadtools.Codecs.CodecsLoadInformationEventArgs.GetColorMask
member.summary: Gets an array of integer values that represent RGB color masks.
member.returns: An array of 3 integers as follows: ColorMask[0] is the red mask; ColorMask[1] is the green mask; ColorMask[2] is the blue mask.

remarks.para: The color mask is valid only if is set to RasterImageFormat.RawBitfields.
As an example, with 16-bit data arranged as RRR RRGG GGGB BBBB, the masks would be:

pre.code: ColorMask[0] = 0x7C00 ColorMask[1] = 0x0E30 ColorMask[2] = 0x001F

remarks.para: For 32-bit data, the only valid data is RRRR RRRR GGGG GGGG BBBB BBBB. The masks would be:

pre.code: ColorMask[0] = 0xFF0000 ColorMask[1] = 0x00FF00 ColorMask[2] = 0x0000FF

java.pre: public int[] getColorMask()

member.name: M:Leadtools.Codecs.CodecsLoadInformationEventArgs.SetColorMask(Leadtools.RasterColor[])
member.summary: Sets the array of integer values that represent RGB color masks.
member.param: An array of 3 integers as follows: ColorMask[0] is the red mask; ColorMask[1] is the green mask; ColorMask[2] is the blue mask.

remarks.para: The color mask is valid only if is set to RasterImageFormat.RawBitfields.
As an example, with 16-bit data arranged as RRR RRGG GGGB BBBB, the masks would be:

pre.code: ColorMask[0] = 0x7C00 ColorMask[1] = 0x0E30 ColorMask[2] = 0x001F

remarks.para: For 32-bit data, the only valid data is RRRR RRRR GGGG GGGG BBBB BBBB. The masks would be:

pre.code: ColorMask[0] = 0xFF0000 ColorMask[1] = 0x00FF00 ColorMask[2] = 0x0000FF

member.example: For an example, refer to RasterCodecs.LoadInformation.

java.pre: public void setColorMask(int[] colorMask)

member.name: P:Leadtools.Codecs.CodecsImageInfo.Document
member.summary: Gets extra information about the image if the file is a document format.
member.value: A object containing the document format information such as its logical size.

remarks.para: LEADTOOLS provides support for loading a document as a raster image. Documents formats such as PDF, XPS, DOC/DOCX(2007/2010), PPT/PPTX(2007/2010), XLS/XLSX(2007/2010), RTF and Text do not contain physical width, height or resolution. It is up to the loader (in this case, the object) to specify the transformation from logical coordinates to physical pixels through a process called rasterization. For more information, refer to .
The class contains properties that specify the original document logical size on disk. This can be useful when calculating the rasterization parameters based on your application viewing needs.

member.name: P:Leadtools.Codecs.CodecsImageInfo.Vector
member.summary: Gets extra information about the image if the file is a vector format.
member.value: A object containing the vector format information such as its logical size.

remarks.para: LEADTOOLS provides support for loading a vector image as a raster image. Vector formats such as DXF, DWG and SVG can be converted to a raster image through a process called rasterization.

Rasterization is the process of converting a vector image to a raster image. To determine whether a certain file on disk (or in a .NET stream) contains a vector image file rather than a regular raster image, call the RasterCodecs.GetInformation or RasterCodecs.GetInformationAsync method and check the CodecsVectorImageInfo.IsVectorFile property.

member.name: P:Leadtools.Codecs.CodecsImageInfo.IsLoading
member.summary: Gets a value that determines whether this object is still loading.
member.value: true if the image is still loading; false, otherwise.

remarks.para: The class supports getting information on image files asynchronously using the RasterCodecs.GetInformationAsync methods. When calling any of these methods, the caller thread will not be blocked and the method will return instantly with an instance that is in a loading status (CodecsImageInfo.IsLoading set to true). You should not use the other properties of this object while the object is in loading status.

When the object finishes getting the information about the file, the various properties of the will be populated with the image file information and the CodecsImageInfo.IsLoading property will be set to false.

It is recommended that you do not poll for the CodecsImageInfo.IsLoading property to determine whether the image information has been collected. Instead, subscribe to the RasterCodecs.GetInformationAsyncCompleted event to get notification on when the operation is completed and whether any errors occurred.

The RasterCodecs.GetInformationAsyncCompleted event data will also contain the same object returned from RasterCodecs.GetInformationAsync so you do not have to keep the original object in your application.

java.pre: public boolean isLoading()

member.summary: Provides options specifically for loading JBIG2 images.

member.name: P:Leadtools.Codecs.CodecsJbig2LoadOptions.LoadOldFiles
member.summary: Gets or sets a value that indicates whether to load old JBIG2 files
member.value: true to load old JBIG2 files, otherwise; false. Default value is false.

remarks.para: Older versions of LEADTOOLS had a problem when some JBIG2 files were saved incorrectly. As of version 17, LEADTOOLS saves these files correctly. If you have files saved with an older version of LEADTOOLS and you are encountering an error when loading these files, you can set the value of to true and try again.

member.name: T:Leadtools.Codecs.CodecsDocLoadOptions
member.summary: Provides the options for loading Microsoft Word 97-2003 (DOC) and Microsoft Word 2007/2010 documents as raster images.

remarks.para: Microsoft Word 97-2003 (DOC) and Microsoft Word 2007/2010 (DOCX) files have no physical width or height in pixels. Use the to control how the final document is rendered as a raster image. For more information, refer to .
For more information, refer to File Formats - DOC/DOCX Format.

Important note: The DOC/DOCX file format supports only the following rasterization size modes:
CodecsRasterizeDocumentSizeMode.None
CodecsRasterizeDocumentSizeMode.Fit
All other size modes will be treated as CodecsRasterizeDocumentSizeMode.Fit

DOC/DOCX also does not support loading a document using different horizontal or vertical resolutions. So if the value of CodecsRasterizeDocumentLoadOptions.XResolution and CodecsRasterizeDocumentLoadOptions.YResolution are different, the DOC/DOCX codecs will use the larger of the two values as the resolution to use when rasterizing.

example.para: This example will load the given Word 2003 file and render it as a raster image
