member.name: T:Leadtools.Codecs.RasterImageTypeConverter
member.summary: is a class that can be used to convert objects from other data types.
member.remarks:
This class derives from the standard .NET class to provides functionality for converting objects from other data types.
The following data types are supported:
containing the URL to the image file with optional parameters.
containing the path to the image file with optional parameters.
containing the data of the image file.
An array of containing the data of the image file.
The method will return true if any of the supported object types is passed into the sourceType parameter. However, this does not mean that the conversion operation will succeed, this depends on whether the data contains a valid image that LEADTOOLS can load.
The method will try to convert the object passed into the value parameter to a valid object.
For and source objects, LEADTOOLS supports optional extra parameters passed as standard HTML query string to fine tune the loading of objects. The following table lists these parameters:
Parameter Description
LeadBitsPerPixel
Resulting image pixel depth. This should be a string representation of an integer. Valid values are:
value Meaning
0 Keep the original file's pixel depth (Do not convert).
1 to 8 The specified bits per pixel in the resulting image.
12 12 bits per pixel in the resulting image.
16 16 bits per pixel in the resulting image.
24 24 bits per pixel in the resulting image.
32 32 bits per pixel in the resulting image.
48 48 bits per pixel in the resulting image.
64 64 bits per pixel in the resulting image.
LeadOrder
Color order for 16-, 24-, 32-, 48-, and 64-bit images. If the resulting image is less than 16 bits per pixel, this will have no effect since palletized images have no order. This must be one of the following string values:
Value Meaning
Rgb Red, green, and blue color order in memory
Bgr Blue, green, and red color order in memory
Gray 12 or 16-bit grayscale image. 12 and 16-bit grayscale images are only supported in the Document/Medical Imaging editions.
RgbOrGray Load the image as red, green, blue OR as a 12 or 16-bit grayscale image. 12 and 16-bit grayscale images are supported in the Document/Medical Imaging editions
BgrOrGray Load the image as blue, green, red OR as a 12 or 16-bit grayscale image. 12 and 16-bit grayscale images are supported in the Document/Medical Imaging editions
Romm ROMM order. ROMM only supports 24 and 48-bit images
BgrOrGrayOrRomm Load the image as red, green, blue OR as a 12 or 16-bit grayscale image OR as ROMM. 12 and 16-bit grayscale images are supported in the Document/Medical Imaging editions only. ROMM only supports 24 and 48-bit color images.
LeadFirstPage
A string that contains an integer representation of the 1-based index of the first page to load.
LeadLastPage
A string that contains an integer representation of the 1-based index of last page to load. Must be greater than or equal to "LeadFirstPage" if specified.
LeadUseWriteableBitmap
For Silverlight only: a string that contains a boolean representation of a value that will be used to set CodecsLoadOptions.UseWriteableBitmap. If this is omitted, false will be used. If you add this parameter with a true value, then the resulting will be loaded with a "WriteableBitmap" as the backend data. Refer to CodecsLoadOptions.UseWriteableBitmap for more information.
LeadUseNativeLoad
For Silverlight only: a string that contains a boolean representation of a value that will be used to set CodecsLoadOptions.UseNativeLoad. If this is omitted, false will be used. If you add this parameter with a true value, then the resulting will be loaded with the native filter codecs instead of LEADTOOLS. Refer to CodecsLoadOptions.UseNativeLoad for more information.
All these parameters are optional and should be passed as a standard HTML query string. The order is not important. Here are a few examples of valid strings:
// Load all the pages in the TIF file hosted at an HTTP URL http://tempuri.org/MyImage.tif // Load the first page only of the multi-page TIF file hosted at an HTTP URL http://tempuri.org/MyImage.tif?LeadFirstPage=1&LeadLastPage=1 // Load the second and third page of the multi-page TIF file hosted at an HTTP URL as 24 bits/pixel with RGB color order http://tempuri.org/MyImage.tif?LeadBitsPerPixel=24&LeadOrder=Rgb&LeadFirstPage=2&LeadLastPage=3 // Load all the pages in the TIF file hosted at an FTP site ftp://tempuri.org/MyImage.tif // Load all the pages in the TIF file in a disk file C:\Dir\MyImage.tif file:://C:/Dir/MyImage.tif file:://myserver/MyImage.tif // Load the second and third page of the multi-page TIF file in a disk file as 24 bits/pixel with RGB color order C:\Dir\MyImage\MyImage.tif?LeadBitsPerPixel=24&LeadOrder=Rgb&LeadFirstPage=2&LeadLastPage=3
The is also used when loading a resource image from XAML as a . Here are a few example:
// Load all the pages in the TIF file set as resource "MyImage.tif" // Load the first page only of the multi-page TIF file set as a resource "MyImage.tif?LeadFirstPage=1&LeadLastPage=1" // Load the second and third page of the multi-page TIF file set as a resource as 24 bits/pixel with RGB color order "MyImage.tif?LeadBitsPerPixel=24&LeadOrder=Rgb&LeadFirstPage=2&LeadLastPage=3" // Load the second and third page of the multi-page TIF file set as a resource as 24 bits/pixel with RGB color order "MyImage.tif?LeadBitsPerPixel=24&LeadOrder=Rgb&LeadFirstPage=2&LeadLastPage=3" // Silverlight only: Load the image and set it as a WriteableBitmap in a RasterImage "MyImage.tif?LeadUseWriteableBitmap=True" // Silverlight only: Load the PNG image using Silverlight and set it as a WriteableBitmap in a RasterImage "MyImage.tif?LeadUseWriteableBitmap=True&LeadUseNativeLoad=True"
Query string are not supported for and an array of data types.
The LEADTOOLS WPF and Silverlight controls use the to load a from a XAML file.
The image returned from the method will have itsRasterImage.IsLoading property set to true since this method will load the image asynchronously. To get notified when the image has finished loading, create the with your own instance and subscribe to the RasterCodecs.LoadAsyncCompleted event before calling as show in the example below.

example.para: This example will use the to load a image from a URL.

member.name: T:Leadtools.Codecs.CodecsTransformMarkerCallback
member.summary: Handles the processing of every JPEG marker present in the file transformed by RasterCodecs.Transform.

returns.para: A enumeration member that determines the action taken by the after the callback is called. Possible values are:

item.description: Successful. The default processing for this marker can be performed
Successful. Do not process this marker and do not write it to the file
Abort the process and do not transform anymore markers

member.example: For an example, refer to RasterCodecs.Transform.
member.param: ID of the JPEG marker. The JPEG markers are uniquely identified by a byte value. Possible values are 1 to 254. (0 and 255 are not allowed.)

A pointer to the memory buffer containing the marker data. RasterNativeBuffer.Length contains the size in bytes of the JPEG marker. The size will be less than 65535. If this value is 0, then the marker does not have any extra data and should be ignored.
Flags that indicate the transform to be performed. These are the same flags passed to the RasterCodecs.Transform method.

objectivec.pre: typedef LTCodecsTransformMarkerAction (^LTCodecsTransformMarkerCallback)(int markerId, unsigned char* buffer, size_t length, LTCodecsTransformFlags transform);

member.name: T:Leadtools.Codecs.RasterCodecs
member.summary: Provides support for loading and saving raster image files.

remarks.para: LEADTOOLS provides many options for loading and saving image files.

Whether an image file is on disk or in memory, you can get information about the image before loading it. You can also handle file-format-specific information, such as the page number or physical resolution.
You can supply the input for a load operation or the output of a save operation, and you can add processing, such as a paint-while-load feature.

You can create as many instances of the class as desired. However, you should not pass a object created in one thread to another. Instead, create another instance of in the thread. If desired, you can copy the options from one object to another by cloning the options from the source using CodecsOptions.Clone and setting in the destination object property.
NOTE: At this time, there are no multipage formats that support stamps.

member.seealso: Loading and Saving Large Tiff Files
member.example: This example loads an existing image file and re-saves it in another format.

java.pre: public class RasterCodecs

member.name: M:Leadtools.Codecs.RasterCodecs.PreloadCodecs(System.Int32,System.Int32,System.String)
member.summary: Specifies the file format codecs to be loaded.
member.param: Number of codecs that should stay loaded in memory at all times.
Number of codecs that should be loaded, but can be unloaded later to make room for other codecs.
A containing the codecs which should be loaded.

remarks.para: If is empty, all file codecs LEADTOOLS can find will be loaded and LEADTOOLS will determine the order in which the files will be used.

is in the form xyz, yuv ... where Xyz are the 3 letters describing the file codec as in Leadtools.Codecs.Xyz.dll. For instance, if is BMP,TIF,CMP then the following codecs will be loaded in the following order:

item.description: Leadtools.Codecs.Bmp.dll
Leadtools.Codecs.Tif.dll
Leadtools.Codecs.Cmp.dll

remarks.para: The first will stay in memory at all times, then the next will be loaded. However, if other codecs will be needed, the cached codecs might be unloaded to make room for the new DLLs.

It is recommended that the most commonly used DLLs be loaded as fixed to minimize the time required to load/unload file codecs. Also, some DLLs may require additional DLLs (like the Leadtools.Pdf.dll or Leadtools.Codecs.Tif.dll) so the exact number of DLLs loaded is not necessarily equal fixedCodecs + cachedCodecs.
Before calling this method, you can get the default preload codecs list using .

member.example: This example preloads the j2k filter and ignores the cmp filter.

java.pre: public void preloadCodecs(int fixedCodecs, int cachedCodecs, String codecs)

member.name: M:Leadtools.Codecs.RasterCodecs.IgnoreCodecs(System.String)
member.summary: Specifies which file codecs LEADTOOLS should NEVER load, even if present.
member.param: A containing which codecs should be ignored and therefore not loaded. Has the same format as in .

remarks.para: Use this method if you never want to load a particular file codec(s). This is useful for instance if you never load AVI files and you want to ignore the AVI codec since this codec on its own loads all the DLLs required for Video for Windows (there are about 10 of them).
The files specified in take priority over the files specified in . This means that if the codec is present in for both methods, then the codec will be loaded and will not be ignored.
Before calling this method, you can get the default ignore codecs list using .

java.pre: public void ignoreCodecs(String codecs)

member.name: M:Leadtools.Codecs.RasterCodecs.StartRedirecting
member.summary: Starts file I/O redirection.

remarks.para: LEADTOOLS I/O redirection allows you to replace the default input/output methods for opening, reading, writing, seeking, and closing files.
For example, you can redirect all the library I/O methods to your own I/O methods to load/save images from your own streams.
Once you call , all subsequent file I/O operation will fire the following events:
remarks.list:
Event Operation
Leadtools.Codecs.RasterCodecs.RedirectOpen
When the toolkit is trying to open a file
Leadtools.Codecs.RasterCodecs.RedirectRead
When the toolkit is trying to reading from a file
Leadtools.Codecs.RasterCodecs.RedirectWrite
When the toolkit is trying to writing to a file
Leadtools.Codecs.RasterCodecs.RedirectSeek
When the toolkit is trying to seeking into a file addLoadInformationListener
Leadtools.Codecs.RasterCodecs.RedirectCloseWhen the toolkit is trying to closing a file
remarks.para: Call to reset the I/O methods back to the defaults.

member.example: This example demonstrates overriding the default IO routines.

java.pre: public void startRedirecting()

member.name: M:Leadtools.Codecs.RasterCodecs.StopRedirecting
member.summary: Stops file I/O redirection and resets the I/O methods back to their defaults.
member.remarks:
LEADTOOLS I/O redirection allows you to replace the default input/output methods for opening, reading, writing, seeking, and closing files.
For example, you can redirect all the library I/O methods to your own I/O methods to load/save images from your own streams.
Call to enable I/O redirection and to reset it back to the defaults.

java.pre: public void stopRedirecting()

member.name: M:Leadtools.Codecs.RasterCodecs.GetInformation(System.Uri,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Gets the specific image page information from the specified .
member.param: The containing the input image data.
true to query the URI for total number of pages; false, otherwise.
member.returns: A object that contains the information about the specified image.
member.remarks:
Specifying true for can cause the process to be slow for files with large number of pages. LEADTOOLS supports the following URI schemes: SchemeDescription
Specifies that the URI is a disk file in local machine or universal naming convention (UNC) path.
Specifies that the URI is accessed through the Hypertext Transfer Protocol (HTTP).
Specifies that the URI is accessed through the Secure Hypertext Transfer Protocol (HTTPS).
Specifies that the URI is accessed through the File Transfer Protocol (FTP).
If points to a resource in a , or , then this will attempt to download image data in an iterative fashion by creating a temporary buffer. The size of this buffer can be determined and changed by setting up the prior to calling this method.
For authenticity and proxy settings, refer to and .
member.seealso: Loading and Saving Large Tiff Files

member.summary: Gets the specific image page information from the specified .
member.param: The containing the input image data.
true to query the URI for total number of pages; false, otherwise.
Page number in the URI to query.
member.returns: A object that contains the information about the specified image.
member.remarks:
Specifying true for can cause the process to be slow for files with large number of pages. LEADTOOLS supports the following URI schemes: SchemeDescription
Specifies that the URI is a disk file in local machine or universal naming convention (UNC) path.
Specifies that the URI is accessed through the Hypertext Transfer Protocol (HTTP).
Specifies that the URI is accessed through the Secure Hypertext Transfer Protocol (HTTPS).
Specifies that the URI is accessed through the File Transfer Protocol (FTP).
If points to a resource in a , or , then this will attempt to download image data in an iterative fashion by creating a temporary buffer. The size of this buffer can be determined and changed by setting up the prior to calling this method.
For authenticity and proxy settings, refer to and .
member.seealso: Loading and Saving Large Tiff Files

member.name: M:Leadtools.Codecs.RasterCodecs.Load(System.String)
member.summary: Loads the specified image file using default options.
member.param: A containing the name of the image file to load.
member.returns: The object that this method loads.

remarks.para: The file can be in any supported image file format and bits per pixel, whether compressed or uncompressed.
This method will load all the pages in a multipage file. The resulting image will have the same bits/pixel and color order value of the image as it was stored in the file.
LEADTOOLS will attempt to load corrupted files so you can see at least a portion of the image. For these images, the load methods succeed, but will return an error code.
Use the class to set up other load option parameters before calling this method.
Support for 12 and 16-bit grayscale, and 48 and 64-bit color images is only available in the Document/Medical Imaging editions.
For supported formats, refer to Summary of All Supported Image File Formats.
LEADTOOLS loads all PDF files as Raster PDF uncompressed RasterImageFormat.RasPdf, regardless of the compression and color space used when saving the file.

member.seealso: Loading and Saving Large Tiff Files
member.example: This example will load all the pages from a single multipage file

Not supported

member.returns: The object that this method loads.

remarks.para: This method resizes a file to the desired width, height, and bits per pixel as it loads. Note that the original file is not completely loaded into memory. This method is ideal for sampling large images (i.e. generating a thumbnail) without the memory overhead of loading the large file itself.
The file can be in any supported image file format and bits per pixel, whether compressed or uncompressed.
LEADTOOLS will attempt to load corrupted files so you can see at least a portion of the image. For these images, the load methods succeed, but will return an error code.
Use the class to set up other load option parameters before calling this method.
Support for 12 and 16-bit grayscale, and 48 and 64-bit color images is only available in the Document/Medical Imaging editions.
For supported formats, refer to Summary of All Supported Image File Formats.
LEADTOOLS loads all PDF files as Raster PDF uncompressed RasterImageFormat.RasPdf, regardless of the compression and color space used when saving the file.

member.seealso: Loading and Saving Large Tiff Files
member.example: This example will load an image from file in a specified size.

member.summary: Loads an image file to the desired width, height, and bits per pixel, resizing the image as it loads.
member.param: A containing the image data to load.
New width of the image in pixels.
New height of the image in pixels.

param.name: flags
param.para: Flag that indicates the type of resizing to use. Possible values are:

item.description: Normal resizing
Linear interpolation resizing
Bicubic interpolation resizing
Not supported

param.name: bitsPerPixel
param.para: Resulting image pixel depth. Valid values are:

item.description: Keep the original file's pixel depth (Do not convert).
The specified bits per pixel in the resulting image.
12 bits per pixel in the resulting image.
16 bits per pixel in the resulting image.
24 bits per pixel in the resulting image.
32 bits per pixel in the resulting image.
48 bits per pixel in the resulting image.
64 bits per pixel in the resulting image.

param.name: order
param.para: Color order for 16-, 24-, 32-, 48-, and 64-bit images. If the resulting image is less than 16 bits per pixel, this will have no effect since palletized images have no order. The following are valid values.

item.description: Red, green, and blue color order in memory
Blue, green, and red color order in memory
12 or 16-bit grayscale image. 12 and 16-bit grayscale images are only supported in the Document/Medical Imaging editions.
Load the image as red, green, blue OR as a 12 or 16-bit grayscale image. 12 and 16-bit grayscale images are supported in the Document/Medical Imaging editions
Load the image as blue, green, red OR as a 12 or 16-bit grayscale image. 12 and 16-bit grayscale images are supported in the Document/Medical Imaging editions
ROMM order. ROMM only supports 24 and 48-bit images

Load the image as red, green, blue OR as a 12 or 16-bit grayscale image OR as ROMM. 12 and 16-bit grayscale images are supported in the Document/Medical Imaging editions only. ROMM only supports 24 and 48-bit color images.

member.returns: The object that this method loads.

remarks.para: This method resizes a file to the desired width, height, and bits per pixel as it loads. Note that the original file is not completely loaded into memory. This method is ideal for sampling large images (i.e. generating a thumbnail) without the memory overhead of loading the large file itself.
The file can be in any supported image file format and bits per pixel, whether compressed or uncompressed.
LEADTOOLS will attempt to load corrupted files so you can see at least a portion of the image. For these images, the load methods succeed, but will return an error code.
Use the class to set up other load option parameters before calling this method.
Support for 12 and 16-bit grayscale, and 48 and 64-bit color images is only available in the Document/Medical Imaging editions.
For supported formats, refer to Summary of All Supported Image File Formats.
LEADTOOLS loads all PDF files as Raster PDF uncompressed RasterImageFormat.RasPdf, regardless of the compression and color space used when saving the file.

member.seealso: Loading and Saving Large Tiff Files
member.example: This example will load an image from file in a specified size.

member.name: M:Leadtools.Codecs.RasterCodecs.Load(System.Uri)
member.summary: Loads the specified image URL using default options.
member.param: The containing the input image data.
member.returns: The object that this method loads.
member.remarks:
The file can be in any supported image file format and bits per pixel, whether compressed or uncompressed.
This method will load all the pages in a multipage file. The resulting image will have the same bits/pixel and color order value of the image as it was stored in the file.
LEADTOOLS will attempt to load corrupted files so you can see at least a portion of the image. For these images, the load methods succeed, but will return an error code.
Use the class to set up other load option parameters before calling this method.
Support for 12 and 16-bit grayscale, and 48 and 64-bit color images is only available in the Document/Medical Imaging editions.
For supported formats, refer to Summary of All Supported Image File Formats.
LEADTOOLS loads all PDF files as Raster PDF uncompressed RasterImageFormat.RasPdf, regardless of the compression and color space used when saving the file. LEADTOOLS supports the following URI schemes: SchemeDescription
Specifies that the URI is a disk file in local machine or universal naming convention (UNC) path.
Specifies that the URI is accessed through the Hypertext Transfer Protocol (HTTP).
Specifies that the URI is accessed through the Secure Hypertext Transfer Protocol (HTTPS).
Specifies that the URI is accessed through the File Transfer Protocol (FTP).
If points to a resource in a , or , then this will attempt to download image data in an iterative fashion by creating a temporary buffer. The size of this buffer can be determined and changed by setting up the prior to calling this method.
For authenticity and proxy settings, refer to and .
member.seealso: Loading and Saving Large Tiff Files
member.example: This example will load an image from a uri

member.name: M:Leadtools.Codecs.RasterCodecs.Save(Leadtools.RasterImage,System.String,Leadtools.RasterImageFormat,System.Int32)
member.summary: Saves a to a file in any of the supported compressed or uncompressed formats.
member.param: The object that holds the image data.
A containing the output file name.
The output file format. For valid values, Summary of All Supported Image File Formats.

Resulting file's pixel depth. Note that not all bits per pixel are available to all file formats. For valid values, refer to Summary of All Supported Image File Formats. If is 0, the image will be stored using the closet bits/pixel value supported by that format. For example, if a file format supports 1, 4, and 24 bits/pixel, and RasterImage.BitsPerPixel is 5, the file will be stored as 24 bit. Likewise, if RasterImage.BitsPerPixel is 2, the file will be stored as 4 bit.

remarks.para: If the output file format supports multipage and then all the pages in will be saved to the file.
If the image is 8 bits per pixel or greater, use the LEAD CMP format or one of the JPEG (JTIF or JFIF) formats to save disk space.
If the image is 1-bit per pixel, use the LEAD 1-bit format or a CCITT Group 3 or 4 format to save disk space.

If the image has a region, the region stored in the image will be saved, if the image is saved as one of the TIFF file formats. For more information, refer to Saving A Region. Note, however, that the ability to save a region inside a TIFF file must be unlocked. This requires a Document Imaging or Medical Imaging toolkit.

Only TIFF and DICOM file formats are capable of saving images that have been window-leveled. Images can be window-leveled by calling RasterImage.WindowLevel and specifying RasterWindowLevelMode.PaintAndProcessing, by using the or by loading an image from a file format that supports Window Leveling. If a window-leveled image is saved as any other file format, the image data will be converted before being saved. For more information, refer to Saving Window-Leveled Images.
Use the class to set up other save options parameters before calling this method.
Use to the Leadtools.Codecs.RasterCodecs.SaveImage event to provide progress feedback or to set or modify the saved image data.

This method supports signed data images, but only DICOM and TIFF formats support signed data. This method will throw an exception if you attempt to save a signed image to a format other than DICOM or TIFF.

In LEADTOOLS version 17 and up, when saving a colored image (such as a 24-bits per pixel image) to bitonal (1-bit per pixel), the object will not use any dithering when converting the image data. This is done because dithering is not the recommended when converting colored images containing text for document processing such as OCR and Barcode. The resulting text will be fuzzy and hard for a recognition engine to process. To save a colored image as bitonal with Floyd-Stein dithering (the behavior of LEADTOOLS 16.5 and earlier) use CodecsSaveOptions.UseImageDitheringMethod along with RasterImage.DitheringMethod as illustrated below:
For information about quality factors, refer to Compression Quality Factors.

member.seealso: Loading and Saving Large Tiff Files
member.example: This example will load a 24 bits/pixel CMP image and save it as 1 bits/pixel TIF image.

member.summary: Saves one or more pages of a to a file in any of the supported compressed or uncompressed formats.
member.param: The object that holds the image data.
A containing the output file name.
The output file format. For valid values, Summary of All Supported Image File Formats.

Resulting file's pixel depth. Note that not all bits per pixel are available to all file formats. For valid values, refer to Summary of All Supported Image File Formats. If is 0, the image will be stored using the closet bits/pixel value supported by that format. For example, if a file format supports 1, 4, and 24 bits/pixel, and RasterImage.BitsPerPixel is 5, the file will be stored as 24 bit. Likewise, if RasterImage.BitsPerPixel is 2, the file will be stored as 4 bit.
1-based index of the first page in to save.
1-based index of the last page in to save. Pass -1 to save from to the last page in .
1-based index of the first output page. If the output file already exists, then this parameter lets you control which pages to overwrite and/or where to append the new pages.

param.name: pageMode
param.para: Determines how to handle the page when saving to multipage formats. This can be one of the following:

item.description: Append the new page(s) to the end of the file. If the file does not exist, this option will create the file and add the pages to it. is not used.
Insert the new page(s) at the index specified by .
Replace the page(s) starting at the index specified by .
Overwrite the page(s) starting at the index specified by .

Use the class to set up other save options parameters before calling this method.
Use to the Leadtools.Codecs.RasterCodecs.SaveImage event to provide progress feedback or to set or modify the saved image data.

This method supports signed data images, but only DICOM and TIFF formats support signed data. This method will throw an exception if you attempt to save a signed image to a format other than DICOM or TIFF.

In LEADTOOLS version 17 and up, when saving a colored image (such as a 24-bits per pixel image) to bitonal (1-bit per pixel), the object will not use any dithering when converting the image data. This is done because dithering is not the recommended when converting colored images containing text for document processing such as OCR and Barcode. The resulting text will be fuzzy and hard for a recognition engine to process. To save a colored image as bitonal with Floyd-Stein dithering (the behavior of LEADTOOLS 16.5 and earlier) use CodecsSaveOptions.UseImageDitheringMethod along with RasterImage.DitheringMethod as illustrated below:
For information about quality factors, refer to Compression Quality Factors.

member.seealso: Loading and Saving Large Tiff Files
member.example: This example will save an image to a stream before loading it back.

member.name: M:Leadtools.Codecs.RasterCodecs.Save(Leadtools.RasterImage,System.IO.Stream,System.Int64,Leadtools.RasterImageFormat,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32,Leadtools.Codecs.CodecsSavePageMode)
member.summary: Saves the specified image to a stream using an offset within to begin saving.
member.param: The object that holds the image data.
A where the image data will be saved.
The offset within the specified stream to embed the saved image file. For example, if you specify 5, then 5 bytes of other data will precede the embedded file.
The output file format. For valid values, Summary of All Supported Image File Formats.

Resulting file's pixel depth. Note that not all bits per pixel are available to all file formats. For valid values, refer to Summary of All Supported Image File Formats. If is 0, the image will be stored using the closet bits/pixel value supported by that format. For example, if a file format supports 1, 4, and 24 bits/pixel, and RasterImage.BitsPerPixel is 5, the file will be stored as 24 bit. Likewise, if RasterImage.BitsPerPixel is 2, the file will be stored as 4 bit.
1-based index of the first page in to save.
1-based index of the last page in to save. Pass -1 to save from to the last page in .
1-based index of the first output page. If the output file already exists, then this parameter lets you control which pages to overwrite and/or where to append the new pages.

param.name: pageMode
param.para: Determines how to handle the page when saving to multipage formats. This can be one of the following:

item.description: Append the new page(s) to the end of the file. If the file does not exist, this option will create the file and add the pages to it. is not used.
Insert the new page(s) at the index specified by .
Replace the page(s) starting at the index specified by .
Overwrite the page(s) starting at the index specified by .

member.returns: The size of the embedded image file in bytes.

remarks.para: You can use this method to embed an image file in another file.
If the output file format supports multipage and then all the pages in will be saved to the file.
If the image is 8 bits per pixel or greater, use the LEAD CMP format or one of the JPEG (JTIF or JFIF) formats to save disk space.
If the image is 1-bit per pixel, use the LEAD 1-bit format or a CCITT Group 3 or 4 format to save disk space.

If the image has a region, the region stored in the image will be saved, if the image is saved as one of the TIFF file formats. Note, however, that the ability to save a region inside a TIFF file must be unlocked. This requires a Document Imaging or Medical Imaging toolkit. For more information, refer to Saving A Region.

Only TIFF and DICOM file formats are capable of saving images that have been window-leveled. Images can be window-leveled by calling RasterImage.WindowLevel and specifying RasterWindowLevelMode.PaintAndProcessing, by using the or by loading an image from a file format that supports Window Leveling. If a window-leveled image is saved as any other file format, the image data will be converted before being saved. For more information, refer to Saving Window-Leveled Images.
Use the class to set up other save options parameters before calling this method.
Use to the Leadtools.Codecs.RasterCodecs.SaveImage event to provide progress feedback or to set or modify the saved image data.

This method supports signed data images, but only DICOM and TIFF formats support signed data. This method will throw an exception if you attempt to save a signed image to a format other than DICOM or TIFF.

In LEADTOOLS version 17 and up, when saving a colored image (such as a 24-bits per pixel image) to bitonal (1-bit per pixel), the object will not use any dithering when converting the image data. This is done because dithering is not the recommended when converting colored images containing text for document processing such as OCR and Barcode. The resulting text will be fuzzy and hard for a recognition engine to process. To save a colored image as bitonal with Floyd-Stein dithering (the behavior of LEADTOOLS 16.5 and earlier) use CodecsSaveOptions.UseImageDitheringMethod along with RasterImage.DitheringMethod as illustrated below:
For information about quality factors, refer to Compression Quality Factors.

member.seealso: Loading and Saving Large Tiff Files

member.name: M:Leadtools.Codecs.RasterCodecs.SaveStamp(Leadtools.RasterImage,System.String)
member.summary: Saves a stamp in an existing file with default options.
member.param: The object that contain the thumbnail (stamp) image.
A containing the name of an existing image file.

remarks.para: The stamp will be written to last page in the file. If that page already has a stamp, it will be overwritten; If the file to which the stamp is being written does not exist, an exception will occur.

This method works for regular JPEG files and Exif JPEG files. For regular JPEG files, the stamp saved is always uncompressed and can be 8 or 24 bits per pixel. The stamp can be any width and height, but the stamp data and stamp header must completely fit in an APP0 marker. Therefore, the size must be less than 64k bytes (0xFFFF).

For Exif JPEG files, the stamps can be uncompressed or JPEG compressed and must be 24 bits per pixel. Exif JPEG stamps are supposed to be 160 x 120. However, LEADTOOLS can save and read Exif JPEG stamps of other dimensions. The stamp, along with other information such as the TIFF_HEADER, 0th IFD, 1st IFD, etc. must completely fit in an APP1 marker. Therefore, the size must be less than 64k bytes (0xFFFF).

member.para: NOTE: At this time, there are no multipage formats that support stamps.

member.param: The object that contain the thumbnail (stamp) image.
A containing the data of an existing image file.

The stamp can be any width and height, but the stamp data and stamp header must completely fit in an APP0 marker. Therefore, the size must be less than 64k bytes (0xFFFF).

For Exif JPEG files, the stamps can be uncompressed or JPEG compressed and must be 24 bits per pixel. Exif JPEG stamps are supposed to be 160 x 120. However, LEADTOOLS can save and read Exif JPEG stamps of other dimensions. The stamp, along with other information such as the TIFF_HEADER, 0th IFD, 1st IFD, etc. must completely fit in an APP1 marker. Therefore, the size must be less than 64k bytes (0xFFFF).

member.para: NOTE: At this time, there are no multipage formats that support stamps.

member.name: M:Leadtools.Codecs.RasterCodecs.StartFeedLoad(System.Int32,Leadtools.Codecs.CodecsLoadByteOrder)
member.summary: Initializes a file-load process in which you control the input stream.

param.name: bitsPerPixel
param.para: Resulting image pixel depth. Valid values are:

item.description: Keep the original file's pixel depth (Do not convert).
The specified bits per pixel in the resulting image.
12 bits per pixel in the resulting image.
16 bits per pixel in the resulting image.
24 bits per pixel in the resulting image.
32 bits per pixel in the resulting image.
48 bits per pixel in the resulting image.
64 bits per pixel in the resulting image.

param.name: order
param.para: The desired color order. Possible values are:

item.description: Red, green, and blue color order in memory
Blue, green, and red color order in memory
12 or 16-bit grayscale image. 12 and 16-bit grayscale images are only supported in the Document/Medical Imaging editions.
Load the image as red, green, blue OR as a 12 or 16-bit grayscale image. 12 and 16-bit grayscale images are supported in the Document/Medical Imaging editions
Load the image as blue, green, red OR as a 12 or 16-bit grayscale image. 12 and 16-bit grayscale images are supported in the Document/Medical Imaging editions
ROMM order. ROMM only supports 24 and 48-bit images

Load the image as red, green, blue OR as a 12 or 16-bit grayscale image OR as ROMM. 12 and 16-bit grayscale images are supported in the Document/Medical Imaging editions only. ROMM only supports 24 and 48-bit color images.

remarks.para: You must call the method to supply buffered data, and you must call when the loading is complete.

This file-load process is useful when receiving transmitted images, such as those on the Internet. It works the same way as the or methods, except that your code supplies the image data. The file-load process works as follows:

item.description: You call the method to initialize the file-load process.
You create a buffer, and each time you fill it with information, you call the method, which sends the data to the file-load process just as if the data were being read from a file on disk.

description.para: Whenever it has enough data to do so, the file-load process behaves the same as in the or methods. It allocates and begins loading the image. It calls your Leadtools.Codecs.RasterCodecs.LoadImage event handler, if one is specified, whenever it has enough data in its input buffer.

The file-load process updates information in the when it has received enough information to do so. The file-load process will make the first call to your event handler whenever this information is available.

item.description: At any time after calling , you can call to gracefully abort the feed load operation. This allows you to end the feed load process without throwing an exception.

To end the file-load process, you call the method, which cleans up the process, and returns the loaded , if successful. If you call this method before supplying the complete file, it will successfully clean up the process, but will throw an exception. You should catch the exception if the load is canceled purposely.

remarks.para: CodecsLoadByteOrder.Gray is only valid for 12 and 16-bit grayscale images. Support for 12 and 16-bit grayscale images is only available in the Document/Medical Imaging editions.
This method cannot be used in combination with .

member.seealso: Loading and Saving Large Tiff Files
member.example: This example will use feed load to load an image from a url

java.pre: public FeedCallbackThunk startFeedLoad(int bitsPerPixel, CodecsLoadByteOrder order)

remarks.para: You must call the method to supply buffered data, and you must call when the loading is complete.

This file-load process is useful when receiving transmitted images, such as those on the Internet. It works the same way as the or methods, except that your code supplies the image data. The file-load process works as follows:

item.description: You call the method to initialize the file-load process.
You create a buffer, and each time you fill it with information, you call the method, which sends the data to the file-load process just as if the data were being read from a file on disk.

description.para: Whenever it has enough data to do so, the file-load process behaves the same as in the or methods. It allocates and begins loading the image. It calls your Leadtools.Codecs.RasterCodecs.LoadImage event handler, if one is specified, whenever it has enough data in its input buffer.

The file-load process updates information in the when it has received enough information to do so. The file-load process will make the first call to your event handler whenever this information is available.

item.description: At any time after calling , you can call to gracefully abort the feed load operation. This allows you to end the feed load process without throwing an exception.

To end the file-load process, you call the method, which cleans up the process, and returns the loaded , if successful. If you call this method before supplying the complete file, it will successfully clean up the process, but will throw an exception. You should catch the exception if the load is canceled purposely.
You can also call the property to determine whether the framework has enough data to load the pages specified in and .

member.name: M:Leadtools.Codecs.RasterCodecs.StopFeedLoad
member.summary: Ends a file-load process in which you control the input stream.
member.returns: The image loaded by the process.

remarks.para: This cleans up all the variables and buffers allocated by the and methods and resets all internal variables to their default settings.
You must call this method to complete a file load that was started with .

If you call this method before supplying the complete file, it will successfully clean up the process, but will throw a file-read exception. You should trap the error if the load is canceled purposely.
For a description of how the methods relate to each other, refer to .

member.seealso: Loading and Saving Large Tiff Files

member.name: M:Leadtools.Codecs.RasterCodecs.CancelFeedLoad
member.summary: This method can be used to purposefully cancel the process.

remarks.para: This method can be used to gracefully cancel a feed load operation. For example, during feed load progressing, the user might click a cancel button to abort the operation. You can then call this method to end the feed load process without throwing an exception.
For a description of how the methods relate to each other, refer to .

member.name: M:Leadtools.Codecs.RasterCodecs.StartFeedGetInformation(System.Boolean,System.Int32)
member.summary: Initializes a file information process in which you control the input stream.
member.param: true to query the file for total number of pages; false, otherwise.
1-based index to the page number to query.

remarks.para: You must call the method to supply buffered data, and you must call when the process is complete.

This file information process is useful when receiving transmitted images, such as those on the Internet. It works the same way as the method, except that your code supplies the image data. The file information process works as follows:

item.description: You call the method to initialize the file information process.

description.para: You create a buffer, and each time you fill it with information, you call the method, which sends the data to the file information process just as if the data were being read from a file on disk.

If the returns true, this means the frameworks does not have enough data to get the information required; you must read more data and call the again. When returns false, the framework has gathered enough data and you can break out of the loop.

item.description: At any time after calling , you can call to gracefully abort the feed operation. This allows you to end the feed process without throwing an exception.

To end the file information process, you call the method, which cleans up the process, and returns an instance of the class if successful. If you call this method before enough image data is passed to gather the information, it will successfully clean up the process, but will throw an exception. You should catch the exception if the process is canceled purposely.

remarks.para: This method cannot be used in combination with .
Specifying true for can cause the process to be slow for files with large number of pages.

member.example: This example will use feed information to get information of an image from a url

member.name: M:Leadtools.Codecs.RasterCodecs.Convert(System.String,System.String,Leadtools.RasterImageFormat,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32,Leadtools.Codecs.CodecsImageInfo)
member.summary: Converts an image file from one format to another, creating a new file in the new format.
member.param: A containing the input file name.
A containing the output file name.
The output file format. For valid values, refer to Summary of All Supported Image File Formats.
New width of the output image. If this value is not 0, then the output file will be resized to the value. Use a value of 0 if you do not wish to resize the output file.
New height of the output image. If this value is not 0, then the output file will be resized to the value. Use a value of 0 if you do not wish to resize the output file.
The output image pixel depth. Note that not all bits per pixel are available to all file formats.
A object specifying more options for the conversion.
member.keywords: Bits per pixel | Color space | Image converter|Silverlight

remarks.para: If you convert to a lower bits-per-pixel format, this method optimizes the colors automatically. For example, when converting a 24-bit file (16 million colors) to an 8-bit file (256 colors) this method selects the best 256 colors to represent the 24-bit image
Note that this is a high-level method that does conversion from all possible formats to all possible formats.

member.example: This example will convert create a that contains as pages, thumbnails for all the CMP images in a folder

member.name: M:Leadtools.Codecs.RasterCodecs.ReadMarkers(System.String)
member.summary: Reads all the metadata markers (COM and APPn) from a file.
member.param: A containing the input file name.
member.returns: A collection of objects containing the metadata marker data.

remarks.para: This method reads all the metadata markers from a file, and returns a collection of the markers.
For Exif files, this metadata collection will contain all the Exif and GPS comments, stored in APP1. It will also contain the audio information stored in APP2.
If the file contains no marker, then this method will return an empty collection.

member.name: M:Leadtools.Codecs.RasterCodecs.StartOverlay(Leadtools.Codecs.CodecsOverlayCallback,Leadtools.Codecs.CodecsOverlayCallbackMode)
member.summary: Indicates which method should be called when an overlay is detected inside a file.
member.param: The method which should be called when an overlay is detected. Use a null reference (Nothing in Visual Basic) to indicate that LEADTOOLS should handle overlays automatically.
Indicates when should this method be called. See for possible values.

remarks.para: Currently, only PTOCA files are known to use such overlays.
PTOCA files contain file references (i.e. filenames) to external files that contain overlay bitmaps. (These files are typically in IOCA format)

These external overlay files will be resized and placed on the current page according to the information from the PTOCA files. By default, LEADTOOLS will load these external overlay files from disk. You should override this behavior if you load files that are not stored locally (for example, on a remote storage or in a database).
To load overlays stored on other storage, you have to pass your overlay callback to this method and load the overlays in your overlay callback.
The overlay callback will be used until is called.

member.example: This example will read a PTOKA file and overlays a TIF file on it

java.pre: public void startOverlay(CodecsOverlayListener listener, CodecsOverlayCallbackMode mode)

member.remarks: Call this method to restore the old overlay handling prior to calling

java.pre: public void stopOverlay()

member.name: M:Leadtools.Codecs.RasterCodecs.EnumTags(System.String,System.Int32)
member.summary: Enumerates all the tags in a file.
member.param: A containing the input file name.
1-based index of the page from which to enumerate the tags.

remarks.para: This method will fire the Leadtools.Codecs.RasterCodecs.TagFound event for each tag found in the file.
Currently, only TIFF and Exif files contain tags.
For multipage TIFF files, you can enumerate the tags from a particular page. Specify the page number whose tags to enumerate.
This method enumerates the standard TIFF tags and the user tags. Standard TIFF tags are less than 32767. User TIFF tags are usually between 32768 and 65535.
To enumerate the tags stored in a stream, use .
To read a tag value, use and to read all the tags in a file, use .
For general information about TIFF tags, refer to Implementing TIFF Comments and Tags.

Do not attempt to use to delete tags from inside the Leadtools.Codecs.RasterCodecs.TagFound event. If you want to delete tags that you enumerate, use this event to add the tags to a list. Upon returning from , you can delete all the tags from the list.
You can use to determine whether a certain file format supports tags.

member.example: This example will show all the tags in the give file, read them then saves them to another file

member.name: M:Leadtools.Codecs.RasterCodecs.EnumTags(System.IO.Stream,System.Int32)
member.summary: Enumerates all the tags in a stream.
member.param: A containing the input file image data.
1-based index of the page from which to enumerate the tags.

remarks.para: This method will fire the event for each tag found in the stream.
Currently, only TIFF and Exif files contain tags.
For multipage TIFF files, you can enumerate the tags from a particular page. Specify the page number whose tags to enumerate.
This method enumerates the standard TIFF tags and the user tags. Standard TIFF tags are less than 32767. User TIFF tags are usually between 32768 and 65535.
To enumerate the tags stored in a disk file, use .
To read a tag value, use and to read all the tags in a file, use .
For general information about TIFF tags, refer to Implementing TIFF Comments and Tags.

Do not attempt to use to delete tags from inside the event. If you want to delete tags that you enumerate, use this event to add the tags to a list. Upon returning from , you can delete all the tags from the list.
You can use to determine whether a certain file format supports tags.

java.pre: public void enumTags(ILeadStream stream, int pageNumber)

member.name: M:Leadtools.Codecs.RasterCodecs.EnumGeoKeys(System.String,System.Int32)
member.summary: Enumerates all the GeoKeys in a Geo TIFF file.
member.param: A containing the input file name.
1-based index of the page from which to enumerate the tags.

remarks.para: To enumerate all the keys stored in a stream, use .
For multipage Geo TIFF files, you can enumerate the GeoKeys from a particular page. Specify the page number whose GeoKeys to enumerate.

The event is called for each GeoKey value stored in the three standard Geo TIFF tags (34735, 34736 and 34737). For enumerating the other standard Geo TIFF data stored as separate tags, you can use . Or, you can call for each of these tags (since there are not that many of them to warrant the use of ).
For more information, refer toImplementing GeoKeys (GeoTIFF tags).

member.example: This example will show all the GeoKeys in the given file and then load them and add them to a destination file

member.name: M:Leadtools.Codecs.RasterCodecs.DeleteTag(System.String,System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Deletes a tag from a file, if the file supports tags (TIFF or Exif).
member.param: A containing the name of the file from which to delete the tag.
The 1-based index of the page from which the tag will be deleted. Use -1 to delete the tag from the last page. Use 1 to delete the tag from the first page.
The ID of the tag in the TIFF file. The tag IDs are between 0 and 65535.

remarks.para: If you want to delete the tag from a particular IFD in the file, set RasterCodecs.Options.Tiff.Save.UseImageFileDirectoryOffset to true, and set RasterCodecs.Options.Tiff.Save.ImageFileDirectoryOffset to the IFD in question. This method will delete tags only from the main IFDs that make up an image. Some TIFF tags are themselves SubIFDs. You can delete tags from such SubIFDs by using RasterCodecs.Options.Tiff.Save.UseImageFileDirectoryOffset and RasterCodecs.Options.Tiff.Save.ImageFileDirectoryOffset specifying the IFD as above.
Notes:

item.description: The Leadtools.Codecs.Cmp.dll codec is used to delete the tag from all the TIFF and Exif files.

Do not attempt to use this method to delete tags from inside the event. If you want to delete tags that you enumerate, use the event to add the tags to a list. Upon returning from , you can delete all the tags from the list.
You should be careful when you delete non-custom tags (tags below 32768). If you delete the wrong tag, you might corrupt the TIF file!.

remarks.para: When you add or remove tags, the tags array at the end of the file is re-written. When you modify existing tags, the new tag value is added to the file and the IFD is modified as necessary. In all of these cases, there is no image recompression.

member.example: This example will create a TIF file, add a certain tag to it then delete it

Notes:

item.description: The Leadtools.Codecs.Cmp.dll codec is used to delete the tag from all the TIFF and Exif files.

Do not attempt to use this method to delete tags from inside the event. If you want to delete tags that you enumerate, use the event to add the tags to a list. Upon returning from , you can delete all the tags from the list.
You should be careful when you delete non-custom tags (tags below 32768). If you delete the wrong tag, you might corrupt the TIF file!.

remarks.para: When you add or remove tags, the tags array at the end of the file is re-written. When you modify existing tags, the new tag value is added to the file and the IFD is modified as necessary. In all of these cases, there is no image recompression.

member.example: For an example, refer to DeleteTag.

member.name: M:Leadtools.Codecs.RasterCodecs.WriteTag(System.String,System.Int32,Leadtools.RasterTagMetadata)
member.summary: Writes or changes a tag to an existing file.
member.param: A that contains the file name.
1-based index of the page at which to write the tag.
Tag to identify the data in the TIFF file.

remarks.para: This method writes tags into an existing file or changes tags in an existing file.
This method works only with TIFF files.

Note: Use this method carefully. LEADTOOLS will not restrict the tags that you write. If you write bad tags, the file might become corrupted. Consult the TIFF documentation for a list of predefined tags. It is recommended that you write only the user-defined tags (the tags between 0x8000 and 0xFFFF).
See the TIFF documentation for a complete list of the TIFF tags and types.

When you add or remove tags, the tags array at the end of the file is re-written. When you modify existing tags, the new tag value is added to the file and the IFD is modified as necessary. In all of these cases, there is no image recompression.
remarks.p: Some restrictions apply to this function if you use an IFD to indicate to which page to write the comment. See the Loading And Saving Large TIFF Files topic for more information.

member.example: For an example, refer to DeleteTag.

member.summary: Gets a comment field from a file.
member.param: A containing the input file name.
1-based index of the page from which to read the comment.
The type of comment. Refer to Types of File Comments.
member.returns: A object containing the comment field information. If no such comment is found in the file, this method will return a null reference (Nothing in Visual Basic).

remarks.para: Some file formats can contain comments, and some cannot, and each file format has its own set of comment types. When you save a file, the comments in the object can be saved in the file. The index into the array (specified using a constant) determines the type of comment.
You can use to determine whether a certain file format supports tags.
To read all the comments stored in a file, use .

member.example: This example demonstrates all of the methods related to comments for TIFF files. It saves a few comments to a file before loading them back

member.name: M:Leadtools.Codecs.RasterCodecs.WriteComment(System.String,System.Int32,Leadtools.RasterCommentMetadata)
member.summary: Writes a comment to an existing file.
member.param: A that contains the file name.
1-based index of the page at which to write the comment.
A object containing the comment data.

remarks.para: This function only applies to TIF, uncompressed EXIF, or FPX files.

When you add or remove tags, the tags array at the end of the file is re-written. When you modify existing tags, the new tag value is added to the file and the IFD is modified as necessary. In all of these cases, there is no image recompression.
remarks.p: Some restrictions apply to this function if you use an IFD to indicate to which page to write the comment. See the Loading And Saving Large TIFF Files and Types of File Comments topics for more information.

When you add or remove tags, the tags array at the end of the file is re-written. When you modify existing tags, the new tag value is added to the file and the IFD is modified as necessary. In all of these cases, there is no image recompression.

member.name: M:Leadtools.Codecs.RasterCodecs.Transform(System.String,System.String,Leadtools.Codecs.CodecsTransformFlags,System.Int32,Leadtools.Codecs.CodecsTransformMarkerCallback)
member.summary: Performs a lossless transformation for certain formats.
member.param: A containing the name of the source file.
A containing the name of the destination file.

param.name: flags
param.para: Indicates the transform to be performed. Possible values are:

item.description: Flip the image vertically
Reverse the image (flip horizontally)
Rotate the image clockwise by 90 degrees
Rotate the image clockwise by 180 degrees
Rotate the image clockwise by 270 degrees
Do nothing

member.param: 1-based index of the page within the source file to process.

param.name: callback
param.para: Optional callback method for processing custom markers. (This is useful for rotating JPEG files only). When transforming JPEG files, the method will enumerate all the markers contained in the file and it will pass them to this callback. The user has the ability to control the transformation for all the markers. For additional information on JPEG markers, please consult the JPEG specification.

item.description: If you do not provide a callback method, use a null reference (Nothing in Visual Basic) as the value of this parameter and no JPEG markers will be transformed
If you do provide a callback method, use a delegate to a method that has the same signature as as the value of this parameter

remarks.para: Currently, only JPEG, CMP and JPEG TIFF formats are supported.
Only one of the rotate flags can be specified.
The files transformed by this method will be read transformed by other applications capable of reading these file formats.

JPEG and Exif JPEG stamps are transformed according to the flags specified in . Please note that some JPEG stamps will not be transformed by this method. Specifically, stamps stored in markers other than APP0 and APP1 will not be transformed. Use the parameter to handle these cases. For example, if a stamp is in the APP14 marker, check for this in the and write your own stamp using .

For JPEG files, the size of the image might be changed. The image width and height is adjusted to be a multiple of 8 or 16 depending on the subsampling present in the image. If the image is 4:4:4, the width and height is adjusted to be a multiple of 16. If the image is 422, the original width is adjusted to be a multiple of 16 and the height to be a multiple of 8. After rotation, the width might become height. If the image is 411, the width and height are adjusted to be a multiple of 16.

The transformation is lossless. It is better than loading the image, transforming it using or and resaving it. Repeated load and save process will cause image degradation, but calling this method will not cause any image degradation.
The rotation transformations are performed before the flip/reverse operations.
Use the method to control how the transform markers are used.

member.seealso: Introduction to Image Processing With LEADTOOLS
member.example: This example will use the JPEG transformation to rotate a file by 90 degrees

java.pre: public void transform(String srcFileName, String destFileName, CodecsTransformFlags flags, int pageNumber, CodecsTransformMarkerListener callback)

member.name: M:Leadtools.Codecs.RasterCodecs.WriteTransformMarker(System.Int32,System.Byte[],System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Controls how the transform markers are used when performing a lossless transformation for certain formats.
member.param: The id of the metadata marker.
A byte array containing the data for the metadata marker.
Offset into into which to begin the read operation.
Number of bytes to read from .

remarks.para: You should use this method to write a certain marker data into the file.
This method can be called only from within the passed to the method.
The transform mechanism is as follows:

item.description: You call .

will call the callback passed to it for every marker contained in the source file. In the callback, you can replace markers, insert markers or allow LEADTOOLS to do the default processing (recommended).

You can override the default action for a marker by returning one of the following values from the transform callback:
CodecsTransformMarkerAction.Default: Let LEADTOOLS perform the default action on the marker. This means the marker might (or might not) be transformed and will be written to the destination file.
CodecsTransformMarkerAction.Ignore: This marker will be ignored (this is useful for stripping unwanted markers). You should also use this if you want to do your own transformation and write the marker yourself by calling .
CodecsTransformMarkerAction.Abort: Abort the process. This will cause to throw a 'user-abort' exception.

remarks.para: Note: You can also use to insert your own markers. The marker will be inserted before the current marker. You can call as many times as you wish. Every call to will insert a new marker.

Warning: Incorrect handling of the markers will generate corrupt files! Since some markers contain important information about the image (image width, height, compression method, colorspace, etc), you should use caution when working with markers.

java.pre: public void writeTransformMarker(int id, byte data[], int dataOffset, int dataLength)

A pointer to unmanaged memory buffer containing the data for the metadata marker.
Number of bytes to read from .

remarks.para: You should use this method to write a certain marker data into the file.
This method can be called only from within the passed to the method.
The transform mechanism is as follows:

item.description: You call .

will call the callback passed to it for every marker contained in the source file. In the callback, you can replace markers, insert markers or allow LEADTOOLS to do the default processing (recommended).

You can override the default action for a marker by returning one of the following values from the transform callback:
CodecsTransformMarkerAction.Default: Let LEADTOOLS perform the default action on the marker. This means the marker might (or might not) be transformed and will be written to the destination file.
CodecsTransformMarkerAction.Ignore: This marker will be ignored (this is useful for stripping unwanted markers). You should also use this if you want to do your own transformation and write the marker yourself by calling .
CodecsTransformMarkerAction.Abort: Abort the process. This will cause to throw a 'user-abort' exception.

remarks.para: Note: You can also use to insert your own markers. The marker will be inserted before the current marker. You can call as many times as you wish. Every call to will insert a new marker.

Warning: Incorrect handling of the markers will generate corrupt files! Since some markers contain important information about the image (image width, height, compression method, colorspace, etc), you should use caution when working with markers.

member.name: M:Leadtools.Codecs.RasterCodecs.StartCompress(System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32,Leadtools.RasterByteOrder,Leadtools.RasterViewPerspective,System.Int32,System.Byte[],System.Int32,System.Int32,Leadtools.Codecs.CodecsCompression,Leadtools.Codecs.CodecsCompressDataCallback)
member.summary: Initializes the buffered compression engine.
member.param: The image being compressed width in pixels.
The image being compressed height in pixels.
The image being compressed bits/pixel value.
The image being compressed byte order.
The image being compressed view perspective value.
Size in bytes of the input image data.
Array of bytes which will be filled with the compressed data.
Index into where the compressed data should be inserted.
Size of in bytes.

param.name: compression
param.para: Type of compression to use. Valid values are:

item.description: LEAD CMP compression format
JPEG File Interchange Format using YUV 4:4:4 color spacing
JPEG File Interchange Format using YUV 4:2:2 color spacing
JPEG File Interchange Format using YUV 4:1:1 color spacing
JPEG JTIF using YUV 4:4:4 color spacing
JPEG JTIF using YUV 4:2:2 color spacing
JPEG JTIF using YUV 4:1:1 color spacing
LEAD 1 bit, lossless compression
LEAD 1 bit, excellent compression
TIFF CCITT
CCITT Group 3 one dimensional
CCITT Group 3 two dimensional
CCITT Group 4 two dimensional

member.param: The callback method responsible for writing or handling the compressed data.

remarks.para: This method initializes the buffered compression engine. The compression is then carried out using the method. It is ended by the method.
If is set to to RasterByteOrder.Bgr and is RasterViewPerspective.TopLeft then the data that you put into the input buffer must be RasterByteOrder.Bgr and loaded from top left.

The compression process starts after the first call to . The is called when the output buffer is filled with compressed data or after completing the compression process. is responsible for emptying the output buffer - storing it, sending it, or doing other processing.
The following is a flow chart that shows the relationship of these methods:
Call to end the compression process started by a call to .

The quality factor of the compressed data is obtained as follows: FormatQuality factor used
CodecsCompression.CmpCodecsJpegSaveOptions.QualityFactor and CodecsJpegSaveOptions.CmpQualityFactorPredefined
CodecsCompression.Jpeg444CodecsJpegSaveOptions.QualityFactor
CodecsCompression.Jpeg422CodecsJpegSaveOptions.QualityFactor
CodecsCompression.Jpeg411CodecsJpegSaveOptions.QualityFactor
CodecsCompression.TifJpeg444CodecsJpegSaveOptions.QualityFactor
CodecsCompression.TifJpeg422CodecsJpegSaveOptions.QualityFactor
CodecsCompression.TifJpeg411CodecsJpegSaveOptions.QualityFactor
CodecsCompression.Lead0Not used
CodecsCompression.Lead1Not used
CodecsCompression.TiffCcittNot used
CodecsCompression.TiffCcittG3Fax1DimNot used
CodecsCompression.TiffCcittG3Fax2DimNot used
CodecsCompression.TiffCcittG4FaxNot used
This method does not support signed data images.

member.example: This example demonstrates low-level image compression using , and . The callback method for writing the output is included at the end of the example

member.name: M:Leadtools.Codecs.RasterCodecs.Decompress(System.Object,System.Byte[],System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32,Leadtools.Codecs.CodecsDecompressDataFlags)
member.summary: Called for each buffer, strip or tile of decompressed data.
member.param: The decompressing context object obtained through .
An array of bytes that contains the raw compressed data.
Offset of the strip referenced by , This is usually zero.
Number of bytes in .
Width of the uncompressed strip or tile, in bytes
Height of the uncompressed strip or tile, in bytes. If the image consists of a single compressed strip, as with TWAIN, this is the height of the image.
Row offset of the tile or strip.
Column offset of the tile or strip.

param.name: flags
param.para: Flags that indicate whether which part of a strip or tile is being processed. Possible values are:

item.description: Processing the beginning of a tile or strip
Processing the end of a tile or strip
Process a complete tile or strip. This is the same as CodecsDecompressDataFlags.Start | CodecsDecompressDataFlags.End

remarks.para: Note that you must call the method before using this method, and you must call the method to end the decompression process.
If does not point to a full tile or strip, set to CodecsDecompressDataFlags.Start when the tile/strip begins and set it to CodecsDecompressDataFlags.End when the tile/strip ends.

member.name: M:Leadtools.Codecs.RasterCodecs.GetPcdResolution(System.String)
member.summary: Examines a PhotoCD file to determine which resolutions it contains.
member.param: A containing the name of the PhotoCD file.
member.returns: An array of 6 boolean values that specifies if the resolution at the corresponding index exists.

remarks.para: For the returned array of booleans, true means the corresponding resolution at this index exist in the file, while false means the corresponding resolution at the index does not exist in the file.
The following table defines the resolution value at each index:

item.description: Resolution 64 x 96
Resolution 128 x 192
Resolution 256 x 384
Resolution 512 x 768
Resolution 1024 x 1536
Resolution 2048 x 3072

member.example: This example checks for a high resolution PCD image and loads it if possible.

member.name: M:Leadtools.Codecs.RasterCodecs.LoadPsdLayer(System.String,System.Int32,Leadtools.Codecs.CodecsLoadByteOrder,System.Int32,Leadtools.Codecs.CodecsPsdLayerInfo)
member.summary: Loads the specified layer from the specified PSD file.
member.param: A containing the name of the image file to load.

param.name: bitsPerPixel
param.para: Resulting image pixel depth. Valid values are:

This method works similarly to a normal or methods, except that it loads only a layer from a PSD file. It loads the layer specified in .
Before calling this method, you may need to get or set file information, such as the number of layers on the file. Refer to .
The number of layers in a file is indicated in CodecsPsdImageInfo.Layers. If this number is 0, the file does not contains any layers and this method should not be called.

member.name: M:Leadtools.Codecs.RasterCodecs.SavePsdWithLayers(Leadtools.RasterImage,System.String,System.Int32,Leadtools.RasterImage,Leadtools.Codecs.CodecsPsdLayerInfo[])
member.summary: Saves an image to a PSD file, along with the specified layers.
member.param: The image to save.
The output file name.
Resulting file's pixel depth. For color images this can be 24 or 32. For grayscale images this can be 8.

An object that contains layers (in each page) to save in the output file. The layers should have the same bits per pixel as the file. Every page in the image will be saved as a layer. The first page in the image will be interpreted as the first layer. The pages in the image must have the same bits per pixel as specified in .

An optional array of objects. If this is a null reference (Nothing in Visual Basic), then each layer will start at (0, 0) and will have the same size as the image. If this is not a null reference (Nothing in Visual Basic), then the layer information for each layer in will be stored here.The number of objects must be the same as the number of pages in .
member.remarks: Use this method to save PSD files with layers.

member.name: M:Leadtools.Codecs.RasterCodecs.LoadCmykPlanes(System.String,System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Loads CMYK TIFF files as CMYK and avoids the colorspace conversion to RGB.
member.param: A containing the name of the image file to load. The file must be CMYK, otherwise the method will fail and throw an exception.

Resulting image pixel depth. Possible values are:
ValueMeaning
8Each plane will be a grayscale 8 bits per pixel image.
16Each plane will be a grayscale 16 bits per pixel image.
1-based index of the page from which the planes should be loaded.
member.returns: A that this method loads. The image will contain one page for each of the CMYK planes.

remarks.para: If the data does not have to be loaded as CMYK, use or .
Support for 16-bit grayscale images is only available in the Document/Medical Imaging editions.
This method will fail if the input file is not TIFF CMYK. Note that not all the pages should be CMYK - it is enough if only the page that you wish to load is CMYK.

Only the following memory load options are supported by this method:
RasterCodecs.Options.Load.AllocateImage
RasterCodecs.Options.Load.StoreDataInImage
RasterCodecs.Options.Load.SuperCompressed
This method uses the values of RasterCodecs.Options.Tiff.Load.ImageFileDirectoryOffset.
If the image being loaded contains alpha channel information, it will be stored in the 5th page of the returned image.
Use RasterImagePainter.PaintCmykPlanes to display the array and SaveCmykArray to save an image as a CMYK TIFF file.

If you want to convert the CMYK array to a regular BGR image and use the other methods or save to a file format other than TIFF CMYK, use ColorMergeCommand and set the ColorMergeCommand.Type to ColorMergeCommandType.Cmyk.
If you have an alpha image, use RasterImage.SetAlphaImage to set the alpha image.
You can apply image processing on each individual image. This allows you to process each color plane separately.
If you want to load a non-CMYK file as an array of color plane, use the normal or method and then use ColorSeparateCommand and RasterImage.CreateAlphaImage method.

member.seealso: Handling CMYK Files as Separate Images
member.example: This example will load all CMYK TIFF file, increase the brightness of the K plane only (which will darken the image) and save the file as CMYK TIFF

member.name: M:Leadtools.Codecs.RasterCodecs.SaveCmykPlanes(Leadtools.RasterImage,System.String,Leadtools.RasterImageFormat,System.Int32,System.Int32,Leadtools.Codecs.CodecsSavePageMode)
member.summary: Saves the pages of an image as a CMYK TIFF file.
member.param: The image that contains the CMKY planes to be saved.
A containing the name of the image file to save.

param.name: format
param.para: Specifies the output file format. Valid values are:

param.name: bitsPerPlane
param.para: Resulting bits per pixel for each plane. Possible values:

item.description: Default bits per pixel. LEADTOOLS will pick the closest valid value.
Save 8 bits per component. The generated file will contain 32 bits (no alpha) or 40 bits (if alpha). Note that or will report 8 bits less (24 or 32-bit).
Save 16 bits per component. The generated file will contain 64 bits (no alpha) or 80 bits (if alpha). Note that or will report 16 bits less (48 or 64-bit).

member.param: Specifies the reference page number when saving a multipage file.
Determines how to handle the page when saving to multipage formats.

remarks.para: This method will save a CMYK file without performing a color conversion. Each page in the will contain one of the C, M, Y, K, Alpha planes. The Alpha plane is optional. The should contain:

item.description: 4 pages if you do not save alpha channel information or
5 pages if you save alpha channel information

remarks.para: The pages are in this order: C, M, Y, K, Alpha (optional). All the pages must have the same width, height, bits per pixel and palette.
If you want to save the pages of the as a file format not supported by this function, use ColorMergeCommand to create a BGR image and save the generated image using the method.

CMYK TIFF files can be saved as planar (each image in its own plane) or chunky (the data from all the images will be interleaved during saving). Planar images will be saved faster, while chunky images are more compatible (some TIFF readers will not read planar files) and require less memory during the load process. The default is to save chunky files.
You select the planar save mode by setting the RasterCodecs.Options.Tiff.Save.SavePlanar property to true.
This method uses the values of RasterCodecs.Options.Tiff.Save.ImageFileDirectoryOffset.

This method can also be used to copy or extract one or more pages from a TIFF file and copy them without recompression to another TIFF file. Whenever you save an image containing a region as a TIFF file format, the region is also saved. Note, however, that the ability to save a region inside a TIFF file must be unlocked. This requires a Document Imaging or Medical Imaging toolkit.

member.seealso: Handling CMYK Files as Separate Images
