member.name: M:Leadtools.Codecs.RasterCodecs.Save(Leadtools.RasterImage,System.Uri,Leadtools.RasterImageFormat,System.Int32)
member.summary: Saves a to a remote URL in any of the supported compressed or uncompressed formats.
member.param: The object that holds the image data.
The containing the output URL name.
The output file format. For valid values, Summary of All Supported Image File Formats.

Resulting file's pixel depth. Note that not all bits per pixel are available to all file formats. For valid values, refer to Summary of All Supported Image File Formats. If is 0, the image will be stored using the closet bits/pixel value supported by that format. For example, if a file format supports 1, 4, and 24 bits/pixel, and RasterImage.BitsPerPixel is 5, the file will be stored as 24 bit. Likewise, if RasterImage.BitsPerPixel is 2, the file will be stored as 4 bit.

remarks.para: The remote URL defined by can be any resource that accepts an HTML "PUT" method. For example, an FTP or SharePoint server.
To setup the authentication and proxy information to use when accessing , use and .
If the output file format supports multipage and then all the pages in will be saved to the file.
If the image is 8 bits per pixel or greater, use the LEAD CMP format or one of the JPEG (JTIF or JFIF) formats to save disk space.
If the image is 1-bit per pixel, use the LEAD 1-bit format or a CCITT Group 3 or 4 format to save disk space.

If the image has a region, the region stored in the image will be saved, if the image is saved as one of the TIFF file formats. For more information, refer to Saving A Region. Note, however, that the ability to save a region inside a TIFF file must be unlocked. This requires a Document Imaging or Medical Imaging toolkit.

Only TIFF and DICOM file formats are capable of saving images that have been window-leveled. Images can be window-leveled by calling RasterImage.WindowLevel and specifying RasterWindowLevelMode.PaintAndProcessing, by using the or by loading an image from a file format that supports Window Leveling. If a window-leveled image is saved as any other file format, the image data will be converted before being saved. For more information, refer to Saving Window-Leveled Images.
Use the class to set up other save options parameters before calling this method.
Use to the event to provide progress feedback or to set or modify the saved image data.

This method supports signed data images, but only DICOM and TIFF formats support signed data. This method will throw an exception if you attempt to save a signed image to a format other than DICOM or TIFF.

In LEADTOOLS version 17 and up, when saving a colored image (such as a 24-bits per pixel image) to bitonal (1-bit per pixel), the object will not use any dithering when converting the image data. This is done because dithering is not the recommended when converting colored images containing text for document processing such as OCR and Barcode. The resulting text will be fuzzy and hard for a recognition engine to process. To save a colored image as bitonal with Floyd-Stein dithering (the behavior of LEADTOOLS 16.5 and earlier) use CodecsSaveOptions.UseImageDitheringMethod along with RasterImage.DitheringMethod as illustrated below:
For information about quality factors, refer to Compression Quality Factors.

member.seealso: Loading and Saving Large Tiff Files
member.example: For an example, refer to Save(RasterImage image, Uri uri, RasterImageFormat format, int bitsPerPixel, int firstPage, int lastPage).

Resulting file's pixel depth. Note that not all bits per pixel are available to all file formats. For valid values, refer to Summary of All Supported Image File Formats. If is 0, the image will be stored using the closet bits/pixel value supported by that format. For example, if a file format supports 1, 4, and 24 bits/pixel, and RasterImage.BitsPerPixel is 5, the file will be stored as 24 bit. Likewise, if RasterImage.BitsPerPixel is 2, the file will be stored as 4 bit.
1-based index of the first page in to save.
1-based index of the last page in to save. Pass -1 to save from to the last page in .

remarks.para: The remote URL defined by can be any resource that accepts an HTML "PUT" method. For example, an FTP or SharePoint server.
To setup the authentication and proxy information to use when accessing , use and .
If the image is 8 bits per pixel or greater, use the LEAD CMP format or one of the JPEG (JTIF or JFIF) formats to save disk space.
If the image is 1-bit per pixel, use the LEAD 1-bit format or a CCITT Group 3 or 4 format to save disk space.

If the image has a region, the region stored in the image will be saved, if the image is saved as one of the TIFF file formats. For more information, refer to Saving A Region. Note, however, that the ability to save a region inside a TIFF file must be unlocked. This requires a Document Imaging or Medical Imaging toolkit.

Only TIFF and DICOM file formats are capable of saving images that have been window-leveled. Images can be window-leveled by calling RasterImage.WindowLevel and specifying RasterWindowLevelMode.PaintAndProcessing, by using the or by loading an image from a file format that supports Window Leveling. If a window-leveled image is saved as any other file format, the image data will be converted before being saved. For more information, refer to Saving Window-Leveled Images.
Use the class to set up other save options parameters before calling this method.
Use to the event to provide progress feedback or to set or modify the saved image data.

This method supports signed data images, but only DICOM and TIFF formats support signed data. This method will throw an exception if you attempt to save a signed image to a format other than DICOM or TIFF.

In LEADTOOLS version 17 and up, when saving a colored image (such as a 24-bits per pixel image) to bitonal (1-bit per pixel), the object will not use any dithering when converting the image data. This is done because dithering is not the recommended when converting colored images containing text for document processing such as OCR and Barcode. The resulting text will be fuzzy and hard for a recognition engine to process. To save a colored image as bitonal with Floyd-Stein dithering (the behavior of LEADTOOLS 16.5 and earlier) use CodecsSaveOptions.UseImageDitheringMethod along with RasterImage.DitheringMethod as illustrated below:
For information about quality factors, refer to Compression Quality Factors.

member.seealso: Loading and Saving Large Tiff Files
member.example: This example will create a multipage image and then upload only the second page to a share point server "Shared Document" folder.

member.name: M:Leadtools.Codecs.RasterCodecs.TagsSupported(Leadtools.RasterImageFormat)
member.summary: Checks whether the given file format supports tags
member.param: The to check
member.returns: true if the format supports tags; otherwise it is false.

remarks.para: This is a helper method that can be used to detect if a certain raster file format supports tags. For example, , and can be used to read the tags stored in a file. If the file format supports tags, such as JPEG or TIFF, then these methods will successfully return the tags stored.

However, if the format does not support tags, such as BMP, an exception will be thrown by the objects. You can use to determine whether the file supports tags and only call the read tags methods if the return value is true.

Note that the option uses this method internally to determine whether the file supports tags when the CodecsLoadOptions.Tags is set to true and only read the file tags if the file format supports them.

java.pre: public static boolean tagsSupported(RasterImageFormat format)

remarks.para: This is a helper method that can be used to detect if a certain raster file format supports TIFF Geo key tags. For example, , and can be used to read the GeoKeys stored in a file. If the file format supports GeoKeys, such as TIFF, then these methods will successfully return the geo key tags stored.

However, if the format does not support geo key tags, such as BMP, an exception will be thrown by the objects. You can use to determine whether the file supports GeoKeys and only call the read methods if the return value is true.

Note that the option uses this method internally to determine whether the file supports GeoKeys when the CodecsLoadOptions.GeoKeys is set to true and only read the file GeoKeys if the file format supports them.

member.returns: A collection of containing all the tags found in the file. If the file does not contain any tags, an empty collection will be returned. If the file format does not support tags, an exception will be thrown.

The tags data will be stored in the resulting image RasterImage.Tags collection.

member.name: M:Leadtools.Codecs.RasterCodecs.UseAsync
member.summary: Creates the object used for asynchronous operations.

remarks.para: The object supports getting information and loading image files asynchronously through the use of the and methods. These methods will use an internal object to perform their operations and this object will be created automatically on the first call to these methods and can be accessed through the property.

If it is desired to create the object manually (for example, to subscribe to any of its event or set the credentials prior to invoking any read operations), you can call to create the object, change its behavior and then call or .

Note: , , , and are only applicable when the or was with the versions that take a parameter. The versions that take a or a does not use a object internally. If you want to check the progress or cancel the operation then use the event as normal.

example.para: This example will use to create the object used by a object for asynchronous operations. It will then change the cache policy of the web client object before loading an image asynchronously.

member.name: M:Leadtools.Codecs.RasterCodecs.CancelAsync
member.summary: Cancels a pending asynchronous operation.

remarks.para: The object supports getting information and loading image files asynchronously through the use of the and methods.

You can call one asynchronous operation per object at a time. To determine whether the object is busy with a previous asynchronous operation, use property. This is the equivalent of the WebClient.IsBusy property of .
You can also use the method to cancel any current asynchronous operation in this object. This is the equivalent of calling WebClient.CancelAsync on .

Note: , , , and are only applicable when the or was with the versions that take a parameter. The versions that take a or a does not use a object internally. If you want to check the progress or cancel the operation then use the event as normal.

java.pre: public void cancelAsync(Object operation)

member.name: M:Leadtools.Codecs.RasterCodecs.GetInformationAsync(System.String,System.Boolean,System.Int32,System.Object)
member.summary: Gets the image information from a disk file asynchronously.
member.param: containing the input file name to query.
true to query the file for total number of pages; false, otherwise.
The page number to query. Pass 1 for the first page (default).
A user-defined object that is passed to the method invoked when the asynchronous operation completes.
member.returns: A object that contains the information about the specified image. See remarks about the usage of this object.

remarks.para: Specifying true for can cause the process to be slow for files with large number of pages.

The class supports getting information on image files asynchronously using the GetInformationAsync methods. When calling any of these methods, the caller thread will not be blocked and the method will return instantly with an instance that is in a loading status (CodecsImageInfo.IsLoading set to true). You should not use the other properties of this object while the object is in loading status.

When the object finishes getting the information about the file, the various properties of the will be populated with the image file information and the CodecsImageInfo.IsLoading property will be set to false.

It is recommended that you do not poll for the CodecsImageInfo.IsLoading property to determine whether the image information has been collected. Instead, subscribe to the GetInformationAsyncCompleted event to get notification on when the operation is completed and whether any errors occurred.
The GetInformationAsyncCompleted event data will also contain the same object returned from GetInformationAsync so you do not have to keep the original object in your application.
will be passed to the CodecsGetInformationAsyncCompletedEventArgs.UserState member of the event data.

member.seealso: Loading and Saving Large Tiff Files

member.summary: Loads the specified rectangle from the specified image file using the specified options asynchronously.
member.param: A containing the name of the image file to load.
A describing the tile/area of the image to load.

param.name: bitsPerPixel
param.para: Resulting image pixel depth. Valid values are:

item.description: Keep the original file's pixel depth (Do not convert).
The specified bits per pixel in the resulting image.
12 bits per pixel in the resulting image.
16 bits per pixel in the resulting image.
24 bits per pixel in the resulting image.
32 bits per pixel in the resulting image.
48 bits per pixel in the resulting image.
64 bits per pixel in the resulting image.

param.name: order
param.para: Color order for 16-, 24-, 32-, 48-, and 64-bit images. If the resulting image is less than 16 bits per pixel, this will have no effect since palletized images have no order. The following are valid values.

item.description: Red, green, and blue color order in memory
Blue, green, and red color order in memory
12 or 16-bit grayscale image. 12 and 16-bit grayscale images are only supported in the Document/Medical Imaging editions.
Load the image as red, green, blue OR as a 12 or 16-bit grayscale image. 12 and 16-bit grayscale images are supported in the Document/Medical Imaging editions
Load the image as blue, green, red OR as a 12 or 16-bit grayscale image. 12 and 16-bit grayscale images are supported in the Document/Medical Imaging editions
ROMM order. ROMM only supports 24 and 48-bit images

Load the image as red, green, blue OR as a 12 or 16-bit grayscale image OR as ROMM. 12 and 16-bit grayscale images are supported in the Document/Medical Imaging editions only. ROMM only supports 24 and 48-bit color images.

member.param: 1-based index of the first page to load.
The 1-based index of the last page to load. Must be greater than or equal to . You can pass -1 to load from to the last page in the file.
A user-defined object that is passed to the method invoked when the asynchronous operation completes.
member.returns: The object that this method loads. See remarks for the usage of this object.

remarks.para: This method loads a section of an image file (any format). The section begins is defined by rectangle.
LEADTOOLS will attempt to load corrupted files so you can see at least a portion of the image. For these images, the load methods succeed, but will return an error code.
Use the class to set up other load option parameters before calling this method.
Support for 12 and 16-bit grayscale images is only available in the Document/Medical Imaging editions.
For supported formats, refer to Summary of All Supported Image File Formats.
LEADTOOLS loads all PDF files as Raster PDF uncompressed RasterImageFormat.RasPdf, regardless of the compression and color space used when saving the file.

The class supports loading image files asynchronously using the LoadAsync methods. When calling any of these methods, the caller thread will not be blocked and the method will return instantly with an instance of that is in a loading status (RasterImage.IsLoading set to true). You should not use the other properties of this object while the object is in loading status.
When the object finishes loading the image, the various properties of the will be populated with the image information and data and the RasterImage.IsLoading property will be set to false.

Do not poll the RasterImage.IsLoading property to determine whether the image has finished loading. Instead, subscribe to the LoadAsyncCompleted event to get notification when the operation has completed and whether any errors occurred.
The LoadAsyncCompleted event data will also contain the same object returned from LoadAsync so you do not have to keep the original object in your application.

member.seealso: Loading and Saving Large Tiff Files

member.param: 1-based index of the first page to load.
The 1-based index of the last page to load. Must be greater than or equal to . You can pass -1 to load from to the last page in the file.
A user-defined object that is passed to the method invoked when the asynchronous operation completes.
member.returns: The object that this method loads. See remarks for the usage of this object.

remarks.para: The file can be in any supported image file format and bits per pixel, whether compressed or uncompressed.
LEADTOOLS will attempt to load corrupted files so you can see at least a portion of the image. For these images, the load methods succeed, but will return an error code.
Use the class to set up other load option parameters before calling this method.
Support for 12 and 16-bit grayscale images is only available in the Document/Medical Imaging editions.
For supported formats, refer to Summary of All Supported Image File Formats.
LEADTOOLS loads all PDF files as Raster PDF uncompressed RasterImageFormat.RasPdf, regardless of the compression and color space used when saving the file.

The class supports loading image files asynchronously using the LoadAsync methods. When calling any of these methods, the caller thread will not be blocked and the method will return instantly with an instance of that is in a loading status (RasterImage.IsLoading set to true). You should not use the other properties of this object while the object is in loading status.
When the object finishes loading the image, the various properties of the will be populated with the image information and data and the RasterImage.IsLoading property will be set to false.

Do not poll the RasterImage.IsLoading property to determine whether the image has finished loading. Instead, subscribe to the LoadAsyncCompleted event to get notification when the operation has completed and whether any errors occurred.
The LoadAsyncCompleted event data will also contain the same object returned from LoadAsync so you do not have to keep the original object in your application.

member.seealso: Loading and Saving Large Tiff Files

Valid values for the parameter are: ValueMeaning
0Keep the original file's pixel depth (Do not convert).
1 to 8The specified bits per pixel in the resulting image.
1212 bits per pixel in the resulting image.
1616 bits per pixel in the resulting image.
2424 bits per pixel in the resulting image.
3232 bits per pixel in the resulting image.
4848 bits per pixel in the resulting image.
6464 bits per pixel in the resulting image.

Valid values for the parameter are: ValueMeaning
CodecsLoadByteOrder.RgbRed, green, and blue color order in memory
CodecsLoadByteOrder.BgrBlue, green, and red color order in memory
CodecsLoadByteOrder.Gray12 or 16-bit grayscale image. 12 and 16-bit grayscale images are only supported in the Document/Medical Imaging editions.
CodecsLoadByteOrder.RgbOrGrayLoad the image as red, green, blue OR as a 12 or 16-bit grayscale image. 12 and 16-bit grayscale images are supported in the Document/Medical Imaging editions
CodecsLoadByteOrder.BgrOrGrayLoad the image as blue, green, red OR as a 12 or 16-bit grayscale image. 12 and 16-bit grayscale images are supported in the Document/Medical Imaging editions
CodecsLoadByteOrder.RommROMM order. ROMM only supports 24 and 48-bit images
CodecsLoadByteOrder.BgrOrGrayOrRommLoad the image as red, green, blue OR as a 12 or 16-bit grayscale image OR as ROMM. 12 and 16-bit grayscale images are supported in the Document/Medical Imaging editions only. ROMM only supports 24 and 48-bit color images.

You should not use the other properties of this object while the object is in loading status.
When the object finishes loading the image, the various properties of the will be populated with the image information and data and the RasterImage.IsLoading property will be set to false.

Do not poll the RasterImage.IsLoading property to determine whether the image has finished loading. Instead, subscribe to the LoadAsyncCompleted event to get notification when the operation has completed and whether any errors occurred.

LEADTOOLS loads all PDF files as Raster PDF uncompressed RasterImageFormat.RasPdf, regardless of the compression and color space used when saving the file. LEADTOOLS supports the following URI schemes: SchemeDescription
Specifies that the URI is a disk file in local machine or universal naming convention (UNC) path.
Specifies that the URI is accessed through the Hypertext Transfer Protocol (HTTP).
Specifies that the URI is accessed through the Secure Hypertext Transfer Protocol (HTTPS).
Specifies that the URI is accessed through the File Transfer Protocol (FTP).
If points to a resource in a , or , then this will attempt to download image data in an iterative fashion by creating a temporary buffer. The size of this buffer can be determined and changed by setting up the prior to calling this method.
For authenticity and proxy settings, refer to and .
The class supports loading image files asynchronously using the LoadAsync methods. member.name: M:Leadtools.Codecs.RasterCodecs.GetRasterPdfInfo(System.String,System.Int32)
member.summary: Gets information for a page in a raster PDF file created with the LEADTOOLS Raster PDF plug in.
member.param: The input PDF file.
The 1-based page number.
member.returns: An instance of containing information about the raster PDF page.

remarks.para: The various RasterCodecs.GetInformation methods are used to return information about a raster image file on disk or stream. Information such as the format, size, dimension, bits per pixel are returned as members of the object returned from RasterCodecs.GetInformation.

Raster Adobe PDF saved with the various methods (using any of the RasterImageFormat.RasPdfXyz flavors), contain extra information that can be obtained using RasterCodecs.GetRasterPdfInfo. This method return an instance of filled with these extra information. Refer to for more information.

member.summary: Gets information for a page in a raster PDF file contained in a stream created with the LEADTOOLS Raster PDF plug in.
member.param: The input PDF stream.
The 1-based page number.
member.returns: An instance of containing information about the raster PDF page.

remarks.para: The various RasterCodecs.GetInformation methods are used to return information about a raster image file on disk or stream. Information such as the format, size, dimension, bits per pixel are returned as members of the object returned from RasterCodecs.GetInformation.

Raster Adobe PDF saved with the various methods (using any of the RasterImageFormat.RasPdfXyz flavors), contain extra information that can be obtained using RasterCodecs.GetRasterPdfInfo. This method return an instance of filled with these extra information. Refer to for more information.

java.pre: public CodecsRasterPdfInfo getRasterPdfInfo(ILeadStream stream, int pageNumber)

member.name: M:Leadtools.Codecs.RasterCodecs.GetMimeType(Leadtools.RasterImageFormat)
member.summary: Gets a string that represents the MIME type for the specified file format.
member.param: A .
member.returns: A string that represents the associated MIME type.

members.member:
Gets the image information from a disk file asynchronously.
/// containing the input file to query.true to query the file for total number of pages; false, otherwise.The page number to query. Pass 1 for the first page (default). When this method completes, it returns the file information as a .
Specifying true for can cause the process to be slow if the file has a large number of pages.
The class supports getting information on image files asynchronously using the GetInformationAsync methods. When calling any of these methods, the caller thread will not be blocked and the method will return instantly with an instance that is in a loading status (CodecsImageInfo.IsLoading set to true). Do not use the other properties of this object while the object is in loading status.
When the object finishes getting the information about the file, the various properties of the will be populated with the image file information and the CodecsImageInfo.IsLoading property will be set to false.
It is best that you do not poll the CodecsImageInfo.IsLoading property to determine whether the image information has been collected. Instead, subscribe to the IAsyncOperation.Completed event to get notification on when the operation is completed and whether any errors occurred.
When this method completes, it returns the file information as a . Loading and Saving Large Tiff FilesSpeeding Up 1-Bit Documents

member.returns: When this method completes, it returns the image as a .

remarks.para: LEADTOOLS will attempt to load corrupted files so you can see at least a portion of the image. For such images, the load methods succeed, but the will return an error code.
Use the class to set up other load option parameters before calling this method.

Do not poll the RasterImage.IsLoading property to whether the image has finished loading. Instead, subscribe to the IAsyncOperation.Completed event to get notification when the operation has completed and whether any errors occurred.

member.name: M:Leadtools.Codecs.RasterCodecs.SaveAsync(Leadtools.RasterImage,Leadtools.ILeadStream,Leadtools.RasterImageFormat,System.Int32)
member.summary: Saves a to a stream in any of the supported compressed or uncompressed formats.
member.param: The object that holds the image data.
An where the image data will be saved.
The output file format. For valid values, Summary of All Supported Image File Formats.

Resulting file's pixel depth. Note that not all bits per pixel are available to all file formats. For valid values, refer to Summary of All Supported Image File Formats. If is 0, the image will be stored using the closet bits/pixel value supported by that format. For example, if a file format supports 1, 4, and 24 bits/pixel, and RasterImage.BitsPerPixel is 5, the file will be stored as 24 bit. Likewise, if RasterImage.BitsPerPixel is 2, the file will be stored as 4 bit.
member.returns: An asynchronous save operation on a object.

remarks.para: If the output file format supports multipage and then all the pages in will be saved to the file.
If the image is 8 bits per pixel or greater, use the LEAD CMP format or one of the JPEG (JTIF or JFIF) formats to save disk space.
If the image is 1-bit per pixel, use the LEAD 1-bit format or a CCITT Group 3 or 4 format to save disk space.

If the image has a region, the region stored in the image will be saved, if the image is saved as one of the TIFF file formats. For more information, refer to Saving A Region. Note, however, that the ability to save a region inside a TIFF file must be unlocked. This requires a Document Imaging or Medical Imaging toolkit.

Only TIFF and DICOM file formats are capable of saving images that have been window-leveled. Images can be window-leveled by calling RasterImage.WindowLevel and specifying RasterWindowLevelMode.PaintAndProcessing, by using the or by loading an image from a file format that supports Window Leveling. If a window-leveled image is saved as any other file format, the image data will be converted before being saved. For more information, refer to Saving Window-Leveled Images.
Use the class to set up other save options parameters before calling this method.
Use to the event to provide progress feedback or to set or modify the saved image data.

This method supports signed data images, but only DICOM and TIFF formats support signed data. This method will throw an exception if you attempt to save a signed image to a format other than DICOM or TIFF.

In LEADTOOLS version 17 and up, when saving a colored image (such as a 24-bits per pixel image) to bitonal (1-bit per pixel), the object will not use any dithering when converting the image data. This is done because dithering is not recommended when converting colored images containing text when performing document processing such as OCR or Barcode. The resulting text will be fuzzy and hard for a recognition engine to process. To save a colored image as bitonal with Floyd-Stein dithering (the behavior of LEADTOOLS 16.5 and earlier) use CodecsSaveOptions.UseImageDitheringMethod along with RasterImage.DitheringMethod as illustrated below:
For information about quality factors, refer to Compression Quality Factors.

member.seealso: Loading and Saving Large Tiff Files
member.example: This example will load a 24 bits/pixel CMP image and save it to a stream as 1 bits/pixel TIF image.

Replace the page(s) starting at the index specified by .

member.name: M:Leadtools.Codecs.RasterCodecs.SaveStampAsync(Leadtools.RasterImage,Leadtools.ILeadStream)
member.summary: Saves a stamp in an existing file with specific options.
member.param: The object that contain the thumbnail (stamp) image.
A containing the data of an existing image file.
member.returns: An asynchronous save operation on a object.

remarks.para: The stamp will be written to last page in the file. If that page already has a stamp, it will be overwritten; If the file to which the stamp is being written does not exist, an exception will occur.

This method works for regular JPEG files and Exif JPEG files. For regular JPEG files, the stamp saved is always uncompressed and can be 8 or 24 bits per pixel. The stamp can be any width and height, but the stamp data and stamp header must completely fit in an APP0 marker. Therefore, the size must be less than 64k bytes (0xFFFF).

For Exif JPEG files, the stamps can be uncompressed or JPEG compressed and must be 24 bits per pixel. Exif JPEG stamps are supposed to be 160 x 120. However, LEADTOOLS can save and read Exif JPEG stamps of other dimensions. The stamp, along with other information such as the TIFF_HEADER, 0th IFD, 1st IFD, etc. must completely fit in an APP1 marker. Therefore, the size must be less than 64k bytes (0xFFFF).
NOTE: At this time, there are no multipage formats that support stamps.

member.example: This example will add a stamp to an existing file before reading it back

member.returns: An asynchronous save operation on a object.

remarks.para: The stamp will be written to last page in the file. If that page already has a stamp, it will be overwritten; If the file to which the stamp is being written does not exist, an exception will occur.

This method works for regular JPEG files and Exif JPEG files. For regular JPEG files, the stamp saved is always uncompressed and can be 8 or 24 bits per pixel. The stamp can be any width and height, but the stamp data and stamp header must completely fit in an APP0 marker. Therefore, the size must be less than 64k bytes (0xFFFF).

For Exif JPEG files, the stamps can be uncompressed or JPEG compressed and must be 24 bits per pixel. Exif JPEG stamps are supposed to be 160 x 120. However, LEADTOOLS can save and read Exif JPEG stamps of other dimensions. The stamp, along with other information such as the TIFF_HEADER, 0th IFD, 1st IFD, etc. must completely fit in an APP1 marker. Therefore, the size must be less than 64k bytes (0xFFFF).
NOTE: At this time, there are no multipage formats that support stamps.

member.example: This example will add a stamp to an existing file before reading it back

member.name: M:Leadtools.Codecs.RasterCodecs.FeedLoad(Leadtools.Junk.IBuffer,System.Int32,System.Int32)

Offset from the beginning of the buffer to where the image data starts.
Total size (in bytes) of the image data.

remarks.para: Use this method with the and methods.
For a description of how the methods relate to each other, refer to .
LEADTOOLS will attempt to load corrupted files so you can see at least a portion of the image. For these images, the load methods succeed, but will return an error code.

1-based index of the page to delete. Use -1 to delete the last page. Use 1 to delete the first page.

The following file formats support delete operations:

PCX
Winfax

member.name: M:Leadtools.Codecs.RasterCodecs.ReadLoadResolutionsAsync(Leadtools.ILeadStream)
member.summary: Examines a stream to determine which resolutions it contains.
member.param: A containing the data of the image file to query.
member.returns: When this method completes, it returns the available resolutions as an array of structures.

remarks.para: A FlashPix, PhotoCD, ECW, JPEG 2000 or JBIG/JBIG2 file can contain more than one copy of the same image, each at a different physical resolution (width and height in pixels).
After you get the available resolutions, you can use any of the following to specify the one to be loaded:
For more information, refer to Implementing JBIG Features.

member.example: For an example, refer to ReadLoadResolutions.

member.name: M:Leadtools.Codecs.RasterCodecs.ConvertAsync(Leadtools.ILeadStream,Leadtools.ILeadStream,Leadtools.RasterImageFormat,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32,Leadtools.Codecs.CodecsImageInfo)
member.summary: Converts an image stream from one format to another, creating a new image file in a stream in the new format.
member.param: A containing the data of the input image file.
A that will contain the data of the output image file.
The output file format. For valid values, refer to Summary of All Supported Image File Formats.
New width of the output image. If this value is not 0, then the output file will be resized to the value. Use a value of 0 if you do not wish to resize the output file.
New height of the output image. If this value is not 0, then the output file will be resized to the value. Use a value of 0 if you do not wish to resize the output file.
The output image pixel depth. Note that not all bits per pixel are available to all file formats.
A object specifying more options for the conversion.
member.returns: An asynchronous convert operation on a object.
member.keywords: Bits per pixel | Color space | Image converter

remarks.para: If you convert to a lower bits-per-pixel format, this method optimizes the colors automatically. For example, when converting a 24-bit file (16 million colors) to an 8-bit file (256 colors) this method selects the best 256 colors to represent the 24-bit image
Note that this is a high-level method that does conversion from all possible formats to all possible formats.

member.example: For an example, refer to Convert.

member.name: M:Leadtools.Codecs.RasterCodecs.ReadMarkersAsync(Leadtools.ILeadStream)
member.summary: Reads all the metadata markers (COM and APPn) from a stream.
member.param: A containing the input file image data.
member.returns: When this method completes, it returns a collection of objects containing the metadata marker data.

remarks.para: This method reads all the metadata markers from a file, and returns a collection of the markers.
For Exif files, this metadata collection will contain all the Exif and GPS comments, stored in APP1. It will also contain the audio information stored in APP2.
If the file contains no marker, then this method will return an empty collection.

member.remarks: This method will always return a thumbnail image. Depending on the passed, this method might read the stamp stored inside EXIF, CMP, JFIF and FlashPix files and return that. To read the file stamp only, use .

member.name: M:Leadtools.Codecs.RasterCodecs.EnumTagsAsync(Leadtools.ILeadStream,System.Int32)
member.summary: Enumerates all the tags in a stream.
member.param: A containing the input file image data.
1-based index of the page from which to enumerate the tags.
member.returns: An asynchronous enumeration operation on a object.

remarks.para: This method will fire the event for each tag found in the stream.
Currently, only TIFF and Exif files contain tags.
For multipage TIFF files, you can enumerate the tags from a particular page. Specify the page number whose tags to enumerate.
This method enumerates the standard TIFF tags and the user tags. Standard TIFF tags are less than 32767. User TIFF tags are usually between 32768 and 65535.
To enumerate the tags stored in a disk file, use .
To read a tag value, use and to read all the tags in a file, use .
For general information about TIFF tags, refer to Implementing TIFF Comments and Tags.

Do not attempt to use to delete tags from inside the event. If you want to delete tags that you enumerate, use this event to add the tags to a list. Upon returning from , you can delete all the tags from the list.
You can use to determine whether a certain file format supports tags.

member.name: M:Leadtools.Codecs.RasterCodecs.EnumGeoKeysAsync(Leadtools.ILeadStream,System.Int32)
member.summary: Enumerates all the GeoKeys in a Geo TIFF stream.
member.param: A containing the input image data.
1-based index of the page from which to enumerate the tags.
member.returns: An asynchronous enumeration operation on a object.

remarks.para: To enumerate all the keys stored in a disk file, use .
For multipage Geo TIFF files, you can enumerate the GeoKeys from a particular page. Specify the page number whose GeoKeys to enumerate.

The event is called for each GeoKey value stored in the three standard Geo TIFF tags (34735, 34736 and 34737). For enumerating the other standard Geo TIFF data stored as separate tags, you can use . Or, you can call for each of these tags (since there are not that many of them to warrant the use of ).
For more information, refer to Implementing GeoKeys (GeoTIFF tags).

member.example: This example will show all the GeoKeys in the given file and then load them and add them to a destination file

member.name: M:Leadtools.Codecs.RasterCodecs.DeleteTagAsync(Leadtools.ILeadStream,System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Deletes a tag from a stream, if the file supports tags (TIFF or Exif).
member.param: A containing the image data of the file from which to delete the tag.
The 1-based index of the page from which the tag will be deleted. Use -1 to delete the tag from the last page. Use 1 to delete the tag from the first page.
The ID of the tag in the TIFF file. The tag IDs are between 0 and 65535.
member.returns: An asynchronous delete operation on a object.

remarks.para: If you want to delete the tag from a particular IFD in the file, set RasterCodecs.Options.Tiff.Save.UseImageFileDirectoryOffset to true, and set RasterCodecs.Options.Tiff.Save.ImageFileDirectoryOffset to the IFD in question. This method will delete tags only from the main IFDs that make up an image. Some TIFF tags are themselves SubIFDs. You can delete tags from such SubIFDs by using RasterCodecs.Options.Tiff.Save.UseImageFileDirectoryOffset and RasterCodecs.Options.Tiff.Save.ImageFileDirectoryOffset specifying the IFD as above.
Notes:

item.description: The Leadtools.Codecs.Cmp.dll codec is used to delete the tag from all the TIFF and Exif files.

Do not attempt to use this method to delete tags from inside the event. If you want to delete tags that you enumerate, use the event to add the tags to a list. Upon returning from , you can delete all the tags from the list.
You should be careful when you delete non-custom tags (tags below 32768). If you delete the wrong tag, you might corrupt the TIF file!

remarks.para: When you add or remove tags, the tags array at the end of the file is re-written. When you modify existing tags, the new tag value is added to the file and the IFD is modified as necessary. Recompression is not performed under any of these cases.

member.example: For an example, refer to DeleteTag.

1-based index of the page from which to read the tag.

item.description: Copyright comment
General Exif comments

Annotation TIFF tag

member.name: M:Leadtools.Codecs.RasterCodecs.ReadTagsAsync(Leadtools.ILeadStream,System.Int32)

1-based index of the page from which to read the tags.
member.returns: When this method completes, it returns a collection of containing all the tags found in the file. If the file does not contain any tags, an empty collection will be returned. If the file format does not support tags, an exception will be thrown.

remarks.para: To read a specific tag stored in a file use , and to enumerate all the tag ids (but not the data) stored in a file use .

This method will throw an exception if the file format does not support tags. To determine whether a file format supports tags, use . You can also automatically load all the tags stored in a file during a load operation by setting the CodecsLoadOptions.Tags property to true. The tag data will be stored in the resulting image RasterImage.Tags collection.
To load all the tags stored in a disk file, use .

member.name: M:Leadtools.Codecs.RasterCodecs.ReadGeoKeyAsync(Leadtools.ILeadStream,System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Gets the specified GeoKey data from a TIFF stream.
member.param: A containing the input file data.
1-based index of the page from which to read the GeoKey.

param.name: id
param.para: GeoKey ID. Values of the GeoKey ID range between 0 and 65535. Possible ranges are:

item.description: Do not use; reserved for future use.
GeoTIFF Configuration Keys.
Geographic/Geocentric CS Parameter Keys.
Projected CS Parameter Keys.
Vertical CS Parameter Keys.
Reserved.
Private use - use to store your own data.

remarks.para: You can use this method to obtain the GeoKey data from a particular file.
If no such GeoKey exists in the image, this method will return a null reference (Nothing in Visual Basic).
The most efficient way of reading the GeoKeys in a file is to enumerate them with and then read each GeoKey with .

remarks.para: To read a specific geo key stored in a file, use and to enumerate all the GeoKeys stored in a file use .

This method will throw an exception if the file format does not support GeoKeys. To determine whether a file format supports GeoKeys, use . The GeoKeys data will be stored in the resulting image RasterImage.GeoKeys collection.

Writes or changes a tag to an existing stream.

This method writes tags into an existing file or changes tags in an existing file.
This method works only with TIFF files.
Note: Use this method carefully. LEADTOOLS will not restrict the tags that you write. If you write bad tags, the file might become corrupted. Consult the TIFF documentation for a list of predefined tags. It is recommended that you write only the user-defined tags (the tags between 0x8000 and 0xFFFF).
See the TIFF documentation for a complete list of the TIFF tags and types.
When you add or remove tags, the tags array at the end of the file is re-written. When you modify existing tags, the new tag value is added to the file and the IFD is modified as necessary. In all of these cases, there is no image recompression.
Some restrictions apply to this function if you use an IFD to indicate to which page to write the tag. See the Loading And Saving Large TIFF Files topic for more information.Implementing TIFF Comments and TagsWorking with MarkersFor an example, refer to DeleteTag.

To read all the comments stored in a file, use .

member.name: M:Leadtools.Codecs.RasterCodecs.StartCompress(System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32,Leadtools.RasterByteOrder,Leadtools.RasterViewPerspective,System.Int32,System.Int32,Leadtools.Codecs.CodecsCompression,Leadtools.Codecs.CodecsCompressDataCallback)
member.summary: Initializes the buffered compression engine.
member.param: The image being compressed width in pixels.
The image being compressed height in pixels.
The image being compressed bits/pixel value.
The image being compressed byte order.
The image being compressed view perspective value.
Size in bytes of the input image data.
Size of output data in bytes.

param.name: compression
param.para: Type of compression to use. Valid values are:

item.description: LEAD CMP compression format
JPEG File Interchange Format using YUV 4:4:4 color spacing
JPEG File Interchange Format using YUV 4:2:2 color spacing
JPEG File Interchange Format using YUV 4:1:1 color spacing
JPEG JTIF using YUV 4:4:4 color spacing
JPEG JTIF using YUV 4:2:2 color spacing
JPEG JTIF using YUV 4:1:1 color spacing
LEAD 1 bit, lossless compression
LEAD 1 bit, excellent compression
TIFF CCITT
CCITT Group 3 one dimensional
CCITT Group 3 two dimensional
CCITT Group 4 two dimensional

member.param: The callback method responsible for writing or handling the compressed data.

remarks.para: This method initializes the buffered compression engine. The compression is then carried out using the method. It is ended by the method.
If is set to to RasterByteOrder.Bgr and is RasterViewPerspective.TopLeft then the data that you put into the input buffer must be RasterByteOrder.Bgr and loaded from top left.

The compression process starts after the first call to . The is called when the output buffer is filled with compressed data or after completing the compression process. is responsible for emptying the output buffer - storing it, sending it, or doing other processing.
The following is a flow chart that shows the relationship of these methods:
Call to end the compression process started by a call to .

The quality factor of the compressed data is obtained as follows: FormatQuality factor used

member.name: M:Leadtools.Codecs.RasterCodecs.LoadCmykPlanesAsync(Leadtools.ILeadStream,System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Loads CMYK TIFF streams as CMYK and avoids the colorspace conversion to RGB.
member.param: A containing the data of the image file to load. The image data must be CMYK, otherwise the method will fail and throw an exception.

Resulting image pixel depth. Possible values are:
ValueMeaning
8Each plane will be a grayscale 8 bits per pixel image.
16Each plane will be a grayscale 16 bits per pixel image.
1-based index of the page from which the planes should be loaded.
member.returns: When this method completes, it returns a . The image will contain one page for each of the CMYK planes.

remarks.para: If the data does not have to be loaded as CMYK, use or .
Support for 16-bit grayscale images is only available in the Document/Medical Imaging editions.
This method will fail if the input file is not TIFF CMYK. Note that not all the pages should be CMYK - it is enough if only the page that you wish to load is CMYK.

Only the following memory load options are supported by this method:
RasterCodecs.Options.Load.AllocateImage
RasterCodecs.Options.Load.StoreDataInImage
RasterCodecs.Options.Load.SuperCompressed
This method uses the values of RasterCodecs.Options.Tiff.Load.ImageFileDirectoryOffset.
If the image being loaded contains alpha channel information, it will be stored in the 5th page of the returned image.
Use RasterImagePainter.PaintCmykPlanes to display the array and SaveCmykArray to save an image as a CMYK TIFF file.

If you want to convert the CMYK array to a regular BGR image and use the other methods or save to a file format other than TIFF CMYK, use ColorMergeCommand and set the ColorMergeCommand.Type to ColorMergeCommandType.Cmyk.
If you have an alpha image, use RasterImage.SetAlphaImage to set the alpha image.
You can apply image processing on each individual image. This allows you to process each color plane separately.
If you want to load a non-CMYK file as an array of color plane, use the normal or methods and then use ColorSeparateCommand and RasterImage.CreateAlphaImage method.

member.seealso: Handling CMYK Files as Separate Images

member.name: M:Leadtools.Codecs.RasterCodecs.SaveCmykPlanesAsync(Leadtools.RasterImage,Leadtools.ILeadStream,Leadtools.RasterImageFormat,System.Int32,System.Int32,Leadtools.Codecs.CodecsSavePageMode)
member.summary: Saves the pages of an image as a CMYK TIFF stream.
member.param: The image that contains the CMKY planes to be saved.
A that will contain the image data to save.

param.name: format
param.para: Specifies the output file format. Valid values are:

param.name: bitsPerPlane
param.para: Resulting bits per pixel for each plane. Possible values:

item.description: Default bits per pixel. LEADTOOLS will pick the closest valid value.
Save 8 bits per component. The generated file will contain 32 bits (no alpha) or 40 bits (if alpha). Note that or will report 8 bits less (24 or 32-bit).
Save 16 bits per component. The generated file will contain 64 bits (no alpha) or 80 bits (if alpha). Note that or will report 16 bits less (48 or 64-bit).

member.param: Specifies the reference page number when saving a multipage file.
Determines how to handle the page when saving to multipage formats.
member.returns: An asynchronous save operation on a object.

remarks.para: This method will save a CMYK file without performing a color conversion. Each page in the will contain one of the C, M, Y, K, Alpha planes. The Alpha plane is optional. The should contain:

item.description: 4 pages if you do not save alpha channel information or
5 pages if you save alpha channel information

remarks.para: The pages are in this order: C, M, Y, K, Alpha (optional). All the pages must have the same width, height, bits per pixel and palette.
If you want to save the pages of the as a file format not supported by this function, use ColorMergeCommand to create a BGR image and save the generated image using the method.

CMYK TIFF files can be saved as planar (each image in its own plane) or chunky (the data from all the images will be interleaved during saving). Planar images will be saved faster, while chunky images are more compatible (some TIFF readers will not read planar files) and require less memory during the load process. The default is to save chunky files.
You select the planar save mode by setting the RasterCodecs.Options.Tiff.Save.SavePlanar property to true.
This method uses the values of RasterCodecs.Options.Tiff.Save.ImageFileDirectoryOffset.

This method can also be used to copy or extract one or more pages from a TIFF file and copy them without recompression to another TIFF file. Whenever you save an image containing a region as a TIFF file format, the region is also saved. Note, however, that the ability to save a region inside a TIFF file must be unlocked. This requires a Document Imaging or Medical Imaging toolkit.

member.seealso: Handling CMYK Files as Separate Images

member.summary: Loads an image file asynchronously to the desired width, height, and bits per pixel, resizing the image as it loads.
member.param: A containing the image data to load.

Linear interpolation resizing

Not supported

param.para: Resulting image pixel depth. Valid values are:

The specified bits per pixel in the resulting image.
12 bits per pixel in the resulting image.
16 bits per pixel in the resulting image.
24 bits per pixel in the resulting image.
32 bits per pixel in the resulting image.
48 bits per pixel in the resulting image.
64 bits per pixel in the resulting image.

param.name: order
param.para: Color order for 16-, 24-, 32-, 48-, and 64-bit images. If the resulting image is less than 16 bits per pixel, this will have no effect since palletized images have no order. The following are valid values.

item.description: Red, green, and blue color order in memory
Blue, green, and red color order in memory
12 or 16-bit grayscale image. 12 and 16-bit grayscale images are only supported in the Document/Medical Imaging editions.

Load the image as red, green, blue OR as a 12 or 16-bit grayscale image OR as ROMM. 12 and 16-bit grayscale images are supported in the Document/Medical Imaging editions only. ROMM only supports 24 and 48-bit color images.

member.param: A user-defined object that is passed to the method invoked when the asynchronous operation completes.
member.returns: The object that this method loads.

remarks.para: This method resizes a file to the desired width, height, and bits per pixel as it loads. Note that the original file is not completely loaded into memory. This method is ideal for sampling large images (i.e. generating a thumbnail) without the memory overhead of loading the large file itself.
The file can be in any supported image file format and bits per pixel, whether compressed or uncompressed.
LEADTOOLS will attempt to load corrupted files so you can see at least a portion of the image. For these images, the load methods succeed, but will return an error code.
Use the class to set up other load option parameters before calling this method.
Support for 12 and 16-bit grayscale, and 48 and 64-bit color images is only available in the Document/Medical Imaging editions.
For supported formats, refer to Summary of All Supported Image File Formats.
LEADTOOLS loads all PDF files as Raster PDF uncompressed RasterImageFormat.RasPdf, regardless of the compression and color space used when saving the file.

The class supports loading image files asynchronously using the LoadAsync methods. When calling any of these methods, the caller thread will not be blocked and the method will return instantly with an instance of that is in a loading status (RasterImage.IsLoading set to true). You should not use the other properties of this object while the object is in loading status.
When the object finishes loading the image, the various properties of the will be populated with the image information and data and the RasterImage.IsLoading property will be set to false.

Do not poll the RasterImage.IsLoading property to determine whether the image has finished loading. Instead, subscribe to the LoadAsyncCompleted event to get notification when the operation has completed and whether any errors occurred.
The LoadAsyncCompleted event data will also contain the same object returned from LoadAsync so you do not have to keep the original object in your application.

java.pre: public Object loadAsync(ILeadStream stream, int width, int height, int bitsPerPixel, RasterSizeFlags flags, CodecsLoadByteOrder order, Object userState)

member.name: P:Leadtools.Codecs.RasterCodecs.FastFileInfo
member.summary: Enables or disables fast file info processing.
member.value: True to enable fast file info processing; false to disable it.

remarks.para: This property causes the LEADTOOLS File Information and Load methods to only check the files signature when trying to determine the files format.

The default behavior when calling LEADTOOLS File Information and Load methods, is that if the files signature does not match one of the known file format signatures, then LEADTOOLS will allow each of the available file format filters a chance to properly identify the files format. This can both slow down an application and unnecessarily use up system resources if the application attempts to load files of an unsupported format (i.e. non-image files).

When Fast File Info is enabled, the file will be rejected if the signature does not match one of the known file format signatures. As a result, the file format DLLs will not be loaded or called unnecessarily.
You must enable this feature prior to calling any LEADTOOLS File Information or Load and Save methods.
The default value is false.

java.pre: public boolean getFastFileInfo() public void setFastFileInfo(boolean value)

member.name: P:Leadtools.Codecs.RasterCodecs.Options
member.summary: Gets or sets the load and save options for this .
member.value: The load and save options for this .

remarks.para: The class lets you set different options when loading and saving image files.
These options are categorized into groups corresponding to the image format they are applied to.
Some of the options are "global", for example, overriding the resolution of the file to load.
You manipulate the options of a certain format through the embedded classes inside the property of this object. For example, to disable MMX when loading JPEG options, you would do:
Alternatively, you can obtain an instance of the correct options, manipulate the values before setting it back as follows:
You can access the various options with the following properties:

item.description: Global load options. Accessed through the CodecsOptions.Load property.
Global save options. Accessed through the CodecsOptions.Save property.
LEAD Advanced Bitonal Compression (ABC) options. Accessed through the CodecsOptions.Abc property.
ECW format options. Accessed through the CodecsOptions.Ecw property.
EPS format options. Accessed through the CodecsOptions.Eps property.

remarks.para: Some of the methods of this class will return an object when called. For example, the or methods will return the object created. If the value of is set to true, then when the or methods encounters an error and cannot return a valid image, it will throw an appropriate exception.
Set to false to cause the or methods to return a null reference (Nothing in Visual Basic) instead when it encounters an error and cannot return a valid image

member.name: P:Leadtools.Codecs.RasterCodecs.UriOperationBufferSize
member.summary: Gets or sets the size of the buffer used in URI-based load or information operations.
member.value: A value specifying the size of the buffer (in bytes) used in streaming operations. The value should be greater or equal to 1. Default value is 4096.

remarks.para: The value of the property is used to determine the size of the temporary buffer used when streaming image file data using any of the URI-based load or information operations.

The following methods will use use the value of this property internally to allocate the temporary buffer:
GetInformation(Uri, bool)
GetInformation(Uri, bool, int)
Load(Uri)
Load(Uri, int, CodecsLoadByteOrder, int, int)
LoadAsync(Uri uri, object userState)
LoadAsync(Uri uri, int bitsPerPixel, CodecsLoadByteOrder order, int firstPage, int lastPage, object userState)
LoadAsync(Uri uri, LeadRect tile, object userState)
LoadAsync(Uri uri, LeadRect tile, int bitsPerPixel, CodecsLoadByteOrder order, int firstPage, int lastPage, object userState)
The default size of the buffer is 4096 (4 KBytes). This means that the object will try to load the image data in 4 KBytes chunks of data.
Increasing the buffer size might enhance the performance while also increasing the amount of memory resources used.

java.pre: public int getUriOperationBufferSize() public void setUriOperationBufferSize(int value)

member.name: E:Leadtools.Codecs.RasterCodecs.LoadInformation
member.summary: Occurs during loading of a file for which LEADTOOLS cannot recognize the format.

remarks.para: The event will occur when LEADTOOLS cannot recognize the image file format during a call to or . This event can be used for loading raw FAX data (CCITT Group 3 or Group 4), raw run-length-encoded data (4-bit or 8-bit), raw Bitfield compressed data, raw PackBits compressed data or raw uncompressed data.

To load a raw fax file, you must subscribe to this event first. When the toolkit fails to recognize the image file format, it will fire this event. If you know the size of the fax image, then set the values in the CodecsLoadInformationEventArgs.Width and CodecsLoadInformationEventArgs.Height properties of the passed as the event data. To automatically detect the width and height of the fax file, set CodecsLoadInformationEventArgs.Width and CodecsLoadInformationEventArgs.Height to -1.

To load raw uncompressed data, you must subscribe to this event first. When the toolkit fails to recognize the image file format, it will fire this event. Set the CodecsLoadInformationEventArgs.Format property to RasterImageFormat.Raw. Valid values must also be set for the following properties:

item.description: CodecsLoadInformationEventArgs.Offset (byte location in file where raw data begins)

remarks.para: If each line of RAW data is padded so that the number of bytes is a multiple of 4 (as is the case with raw Windows BMP data), set CodecsLoadInformationEventArgs.Pad4 to true. Include an orientation in the CodecsLoadInformationEventArgs.ViewPerspective to load with the proper orientation. For example, raw Windows BMP data is stored with a RasterViewPerspective.BottomLeft orientation. If the orientation is unknown, then set it to RasterViewPerspective.BottomLeft. If the raw data is 8 bits per pixel or less, then the image is palettized and a palette must be generated. If this is the case, pass in a valid palette with 1 >gt; bits/pixel number of entries to the CodecsLoadInformationEventArgs.SetPalette method.
Set the correct color order in the CodecsLoadInformationEventArgs.Order property. For example, if the order of the data is BGR, then set this value to RasterByteOrder.Bgr.
For more information, refer to .

member.example: This example demonstrates saving and loading raw/headerless image files.

java.pre: synchronized public void addLoadInformationListener(CodecsLoadInformationListener listener) synchronized public void removeLoadInformationListener(CodecsLoadInformationListener listener)

member.name: P:Leadtools.Codecs.RasterCodecs.LoadStatus
member.summary: Gets a value that allows the detection of whether the image was loaded with errors.

value.para: A which indicates the result of the most recent load operation.
The most common return values are:

item.description: The image loaded by the last load call does not have any errors.
There were errors decoding the last image. The bottom part of the image might be corrupted.

Some of the resync markers were incorrect or missing while decoding the last image. Resync markers are used by JPEG files to recover from decoding errors. Portions of the image are corrupted. They are indicated by a checkerboard pattern.
The file was truncated. The bottom part of the image is missing.

remarks.para: An error return code is a warning that portions of the image that was last loaded might be corrupted.

This property should be called after a load method has been successfully called. This value is reset after each page is loaded, so if you are loading multiple pages, this error code is valid only for the last page.
If the last load method threw an exception, then this method should not be used, as its return value is undefined.
Note that this property is valid for the current thread. So it should be used in the same thread as the load method.
This is valid for all the methods that will load an image, including , and .

member.example: This example will load an image and checks whether the image has corrupted areas

java.pre: public RasterExceptionCode getLoadStatus()

remarks.para: Note: The restriction on using portions of LEADTOOLS inside ASP.NET applications has been removed starting with LEADTOOLS 16.5.

The object has the following methods that allows you to resize an image while it is being loaded:
Load(string fileName, int width, int height, int bitsPerPixel, RasterSizeFlags flags, CodecsLoadByteOrder order)
Load(string fileName, int width, int height, int bitsPerPixel, RasterSizeFlags flags, CodecsLoadByteOrder order, int firstPage, int lastPage)

This method works by resizing the image while it is being loaded using an internal thread. To disable this behavior, you can set the value of the property to true to completely load an image before resizing it.

member.summary: Gets the object used for asynchronous operations.

If it is desired to create the object manually (for example, to subscribe to any of its event or set the credentials prior to invoking any read operations), you can call to create the object, change its behavior and then call or .

Note: , , , and are only applicable when the or was with the versions that take a parameter. The versions that take a or a does not use a object internally. If you want to check the progress or cancel the operation then use the event as normal.

You can call one asynchronous operation per object at a time. To determine whether the object is busy with a previous asynchronous operation, use property. This is the equivalent of the WebClient.IsBusy property of .
You can also use the method to cancel any current asynchronous operation in this object. This is the equivalent of calling WebClient.CancelAsync on .

Note: , , , and are only applicable when the or was with the versions that take a parameter. The versions that take a or a does not use a object internally. If you want to check the progress or cancel the operation then use the event as normal.

member.name: E:Leadtools.Codecs.RasterCodecs.GetInformationAsyncCompleted
member.summary: Indicates that an asynchronous get information operation has been completed.

remarks.para: The class supports getting information on image files asynchronously using the GetInformationAsync methods. When calling any of these methods, the caller thread will not be blocked and the method will return instantly with an instance that is in a loading status (CodecsImageInfo.IsLoading set to true). You should not use the other properties of this object while the object is in loading status.

When the object finishes getting the information about the file, the various properties of the will be populated with the image file information and the CodecsImageInfo.IsLoading property will be set to false.

It is recommended that you do not poll for the CodecsImageInfo.IsLoading property to determine whether the image information has been collected. Instead, subscribe to the GetInformationAsyncCompleted event to get notification on when the operation is completed and whether any errors occurred.
The GetInformationAsyncCompleted event data will also contain the same object returned from GetInformationAsync so you do not have to keep the original object in your application.
The GetInformationAsyncCompleted event uses a data argument object of type . This class contains the following properties:

description.para: Contains the URI, stream or file name passed to the method that initialized this asynchronous operation.

Only one of these properties can be a valid value (not a null reference) at any time The property that contains a valid reference depends on what version of GetInformationAsync method has been called.

For example, if GetInformationAsync(Uri uri, bool totalPages, int pageNumberobject, object userState) is being called, the will contain the same URI passed to the method while and will both be null. If GetInformationAsync(string fileName, bool totalPages, int pageNumberobject, object userState) is being called, the will contain the same file name string value passed to the method while and will both be null and so on.

Contains the class instance that contains the information about the image file. This instance is the same object returned from the GetInformationAsync method. While the asynchronous operation is running, the value of the CodecsImageInfo.IsLoading will be true indicating that the object is being populated with the information and should not be used. When the asynchronous operation completes, the GetInformationAsyncCompleted event will fire and Info will contain the final and ready to use object. If an error occurs, this property will be set to null and the object is disposed internally by the toolkit.

Contains any errors that might have occurred during the asynchronous operation. You must check this value when the GetInformationAsyncCompleted event fires and make sure it does not contain a valid object.
Contains a value indicating whether an asynchronous operation has been canceled. For example, by calling CancelAsync when using RasterCodecs.GetInformationAsync with a URL.

java.pre: synchronized public void addGetInformationAsyncCompletedListener(CodecsGetInformationAsyncCompletedListener listener) synchronized public void removeGetInformationAsyncCompletedListener(CodecsGetInformationAsyncCompletedListener listener)

member.name: E:Leadtools.Codecs.RasterCodecs.LoadAsyncCompleted
member.summary: Indicates that an asynchronous load operation has been completed.

remarks.para: The class supports loading image files asynchronously using the LoadAsync methods. When calling any of these methods, the caller thread will not be blocked and the method will return instantly with an instance of that is in a loading status (RasterImage.IsLoading set to true). You should not use the other properties of this object while the object is in loading status.
When the object finishes loading the image, the various properties of the will be populated with the image information and data and the RasterImage.IsLoading property will be set to false.

It is recommended that you do not poll for the RasterImage.IsLoading property to determine whether the image is finished loaded, instead, subscribe to the LoadAsyncCompleted event to get notification on when the operation is completed and whether any errors occurred.
The LoadAsyncCompleted event data will also contain the same object returned from LoadAsync so you do not have to keep the original object in your application.
The LoadAsyncCompleted event uses a data argument object of type . This class contains the following properties:

description.para: Contains the URI, stream or file name passed to the method that initialized this asynchronous operation.
Only one of these properties can be a valid value (not a null reference) at any time The property that contains a valid reference depends on what version of LoadAsync method has been called.

For example, if LoadAsync(Uri uri, object userState) is being called, the will contain the same URI passed to the method while and will both be null. If LoadAsync(String fileName, object userState) is being called, the will contain the same file name string value passed to the method while and will both be null and so on.

Contains the class instance that contains the image data being loaded. This instance is the same object returned from the LoadAsync method. While the asynchronous operation is running, the value of the RasterImage.IsLoading will be true indicating that the object is being populated with the image information and should not be used. When the asynchronous operation completes, the LoadAsyncCompleted event will fire and Image will contain the final and ready to use object. If an error occurs, this property will be set to null and the object is disposed internally by the toolkit.
Contains any errors that might have occurred during the asynchronous operation. You must check this value when the LoadAsyncCompleted event fires and make sure it does not contain a valid object.
Contains a value indicating whether an asynchronous operation has been canceled. For example, by calling CancelAsync when using RasterCodecs.LoadAsync with a URL.

java.pre: synchronized public void addLoadAsyncCompletedListener(CodecsLoadAsyncCompletedListener listener) synchronized public void removeLoadAsyncCompletedListener(CodecsLoadAsyncCompletedListener listener)

member.name: F:Leadtools.Codecs.CodecsVectorViewMode.UseWidthAndHeight
member.summary: Use the specified CodecsVectorLoadOptions.ViewWidth. Calculate new height, preserving the aspect ratio. Final image size has the same width as the current CodecsVectorLoadOptions.ViewWidth, with the height less than or equal to the current CodecsVectorLoadOptions.ViewHeight.

member.name: F:Leadtools.Codecs.CodecsVectorViewMode.UseWidth
member.summary: Use the current CodecsVectorLoadOptions.ViewHeight. Calculate the new width, preserving the aspect ratio. Final image size has the same height as the current CodecsVectorLoadOptions.ViewHeight, with the width less than or equal to the current CodecsVectorLoadOptions.ViewWidth.

member.name: F:Leadtools.Codecs.CodecsVectorViewMode.UseHeight
member.summary: Use both the CodecsVectorLoadOptions.ViewWidth and the CodecsVectorLoadOptions.ViewHeight (stretch image if necessary). Final image size has the same width and height as the current viewport size.

member.name: T:Leadtools.Codecs.CodecsVectorLoadOptions
member.summary: Contains options for loading a vector file as a raster image (rasterization).

remarks.para: LEADTOOLS provides support for loading a vector image as a raster image. Vector formats such as DXF, DWG and SVG can be converted to a raster image through a process called rasterization.

Rasterization is the process of converting a vector image to a raster image. To determine whether a certain file on disk (or in a .NET stream) contains a vector image file rather than a regular raster image, call the RasterCodecs.GetInformation or RasterCodecs.GetInformationAsync method and check the CodecsVectorImageInfo.IsVectorFile property. Here is a code snippet:
To rasterize a vector image file, set the properties of the to the desired values, and then call the RasterCodecs.Load or RasterCodecs.LoadAsync methods.

A vector image file format usually does not have a physical size. The user can specify a viewport (physical size up to which the drawing can be rendered) and . How the drawing is to be rendered inside this viewport depends on the current viewport mode set with . Default viewport size is 640x480 pixels.

member.name: P:Leadtools.Codecs.CodecsVectorLoadOptions.ViewWidth
member.summary: Gets or sets the desired width of the viewport for rasterizing vector image files.
member.value: The width of the viewport in pixels.

remarks.para: A vector image file format usually does not have a physical size. The user can specify a viewport (physical size up to which the drawing can be rendered) and . How the drawing is to be rendered inside this viewport depends on the current viewport mode set with . Default viewport size is 640x480 pixels.

member.name: P:Leadtools.Codecs.CodecsVectorLoadOptions.ViewHeight
member.summary: Gets or sets the desired height of the viewport for rasterizing vector image files.
member.value: The height of the viewport in pixels.

remarks.para: A vector image file format usually does not have a physical size. The user can specify a viewport (physical size up to which the drawing can be rendered) and . How the drawing is to be rendered inside this viewport depends on the current viewport mode set with . Default viewport size is 640x480 pixels.

member.summary: Gets or sets the that controls the actual size of the viewport when rasterizing vector image files.
member.value: A that controls the actual size of the viewport when rasterizing vector image files.

remarks.para: A vector image file format usually does not have a physical size. The user can specify a viewport (physical size up to which the drawing can be rendered) and . How the drawing is to be rendered inside this viewport depends on the current viewport mode set with . Default viewport size is 640x480 pixels.

member.name: P:Leadtools.Codecs.CodecsVectorLoadOptions.BitsPerPixel
member.summary: Gets or sets the target bits per pixel for the resulting raster image when rasterizing vector image files.
member.value: The target bits per pixel for the resulting raster image when rasterizing vector image files.

remarks.para: A vector image file format usually does not have a physical size. The user can specify a viewport (physical size up to which the drawing can be rendered) and . How the drawing is to be rendered inside this viewport depends on the current viewport mode set with . Default viewport size is 640x480 pixels.

member.summary: Enables or disables the use of the BackgroundColor when rasterizing vector image files.

member.name: P:Leadtools.Codecs.CodecsVectorLoadOptions.BackgroundColor
member.summary: Gets or sets the background color to be used when rasterizing vector image files.
member.value: The background color to be used when rasterizing vector image files.

remarks.para: If the vector image file being rasterized does not specify a background color, the value of this property will be used to fill the resulting raster image during rasterization.
You can override the value specified in the vector image file by setting to true.

member.name: T:Leadtools.Codecs.CodecsVectorOptions
member.summary: Provides support for loading or saving a vector image file.

remarks.para: LEADTOOLS provides support for loading a vector image as a raster image. Vector formats such as DXF, DWG and SVG can be converted to a raster image through a process called rasterization.

member.name: P:Leadtools.Codecs.CodecsVectorOptions.Load
member.summary: Gets the object used to set the options for loading a vector image file as a raster image.
member.value: An instance of object that contains the options to use for loading a vector image file as a raster image.

remarks.para: LEADTOOLS provides support for loading a vector image as a raster image. Vector formats such as DXF, DWG and SVG can be converted to a raster image through a process called rasterization.

member.name: P:Leadtools.Codecs.CodecsLoadImageEventArgs.PagePercent
member.summary: Gets the load completion percentage of the current page.
member.value: A number between 0 and 100 that indicates the completion percentage of the load operation of the current page.

remarks.para: Using the and properties, you can use the to show a progress bar of the current load operation.

When loading a multi-page file, will go from 0 to 100 for each page loaded while will go from 0 to 100 only once during the whole page operation. Usually, you will use to show an overall load progress if the multi-page image is considered to be one document. If however, individual progress is required for each page, then you can track the property as well.
When loading a single page file or one page from a multi-page file, both and will go from 0 to 100 simultaneously.

member.example: For an example, refer to RasterCodecs.LoadImage.

java.pre: public int getPagePercent()

member.name: P:Leadtools.Codecs.CodecsLoadImageEventArgs.TotalPercent
member.summary: Gets the overall completion percentage for the load operation.
member.value: A number between 0 and 100 that indicates the overall completion percentage of the load operation.

remarks.para: Using the and properties, you can use the to show a progress bar of the current load operation.

When loading a multi-page file, will go from 0 to 100 for each page loaded while will go from 0 to 100 only once during the whole page operation. Usually, you will use to show an overall load progress if the multi-page image is considered to be one document. If however, individual progress is required for each page, then you can track the property as well.
When loading a single page file or one page from a multi-page file, both and will go from 0 to 100 simultaneously.

member.example: For an example, refer to RasterCodecs.LoadImage.

java.pre: public int getTotalPercent()
